Chalamet's character is supposed to be 17, which would make Hammer's actions illegal in some places, and just plain creepy in others. I guess that's why the story takes place in Italy. The film is a pretty picture that combines child sex/romance with very slow pacing, interminable still art shots and the very long run time. I would avoid unless you like slow moving European arthouse flicks with a Lolita like storyline. In fairness, I would give this movie a zero while my wife and friends would give it a 6, hence the 3. It's very hard to comprehend love and romance between two same sex gender people, some pundits even categorically deny the fact that they can love outside conventional male/female relationships, to show this in a film and hold you until the end it's a superhero job, which was done by 'Luca Guadagnino' an utterly gorgeous film making, score, cinematography and performance by two main roles were speechless, I could never understand same sex emotions in their love until I stand on their position, this film emotionally put me on that position and let me feel that on screen. I had goosebumps after watching a super sensible conversation between the father and son, dialogues were written artistically perfect, performance by Timothee aka Elio was astonishing, it was one of the bests drama I've enjoyed lately.Love, romance and agony between two homosexual men were depicted superbly. Pre intercourse moment between two men, ohhh hoo hoo ... I doubt I've seen a better version before.Score and two songs - 'Mystery of Love' and 'Vision of Gideon' just awesome composition.And, I cannot end without praising the supporting role, by 'Armie Hammer' perhaps, it's the most perfect support ever an actor supported I think 😊. His body language and dialogue delivery were outstanding. He's the second star of the film, I read somewhere that, there are three stars in Luca Guadignino's beautiful new film: Armie Hammer, Timothee Chalamet and the northern Italian city of Crema.
Absolutely 👍.I do not want to spoil by telling a moment when Armie aka Oliver asked Elio ... ... ... I will let you enjoy that guys, it was an excellent moment, and his last conversation with Elio, It was so good film making that even on voice over from the other side of the phone call you can feel love, romance and agony.Call me by your name is full of joy, emotional, devastating and full-hearted romantic masterpiece.

"Call Me By Your Name" is a marvelous meditation on first true love on a gay theme. The director, Luca Guadagnino, has created a film that simply refuses to force anything upon the viewer. The film is a masterful study of direction as observation-of letting things be as they are. Timotheé Chalamet is a joy to behold on screen as a coming of age youth in the throws of self-identification and self-legitimization. His late-pubescent struggles with societal constraints and self-inflicted moral dilemmas permeate his nascent feelings for a mid-20s scholar who has come to assist his father at the family's Northern Italy summer retreat. It is an Oscar worthy performance-at once charming, evocative and tender. Armie Hammer's brusque and intelligent performance as the American scholar is also noteworthy. HIs scenes take us by ambush. As hawt as he is to look at, one can't help but be reminded of a rhinoceros charging out of underbrush when his character enters a room. A rare new experience unfolds for these tentative lovers who find themselves in an era (the 80s) of overall non-acceptance. One gets the feeling, too, that this experience as it develops will never again be repeated. Interestingly, the AIDS epidemic does not touch this film. In my opinion, a wise decision by the director who transports us to a place of transcendent beauty, as first love ought to be. Love here is remote, fragile, un-worldly, and yet all-knowing, brave, undeniable. It is difficult to create a film so clear and direct in its depiction of life's ambiguities. I didn't want the film to end. A pleasure through and through.

reviews.review_title: Candor and Reluctant inside an arena.
reviews.content: The story was great. Without a doubt. And as someone who was a heteroflexible dude who understands perfectly how to like another of my own gender, it's almost inevitable not to have a connection with both of the main characters: Elio & Oliver. What surpised me most was how the film was set on somewhere in the early 1980's or late 1970's... regardles, with that in mind, I was baffled by how good the phasing was! It's not that typical immediate mutual understanding, but a rather twisted overthinking of both sides if they wanted it or not, let alone if they know it or not. And I would like to commend the director and the writers for the flow was thoroughly patient. I felt like there were none of those 'hurry up and be together already' moments, rather, it was shown to the viewers to think what would happen next.Now going to the characters. I love them! Elio, a charming wittyful young lad who has a knack for subtle competition. Oliver, an uncanny unpredictable man who worries for others than his own good. A perfect combination. The intelligent lad trying to figure out the mysterious man who keeps everything under his nose. What about that?!As for the relationship. I'm glad to see it built up from nothing and constantly, slowly, softly and gradualy growing. I thought for sure that they would only do some kissing before Oliver finally goes back to where he came from, but no, an even more bizzare scenarios happened. The euphoria and how two people can have so much fun only by themselves. Yet, in the end, as most similar relationships to them, do end up in a heartbreaking farewell.And then there's the ending, Elio finally gets to talk to Oliver when winter fell but learns that he is already betrothed to another who he has been going on and off for three years. The look on his face, knowing that he is mad, angry, frustrated, all emotions blue, yet he must keep it on the down low. At first he was just that, then as the credits roll, we can see his expression getting more calm by the minute and finally a smile appeared, as if he was ready to accept the fact that it is what it is. He tumbled unto his thoughts and tears until his mother called him up back to the reality, facing away from the camera as if telling the audience that it is over.Call Me by Your Name (And I'll Call You by Yours) is ridiculously well written and is a marvelous film indeed. Rating it 8.5/10 in my book. I can say I would watch this film again if given a chance.

To me, this film was pretty much perfection.It's a beautiful film, set in a beautiful rural Italian setting with a stunning cast. Thanks to both the actors and its production, its remains authentic in nature and never goes off into unrealistic tangents. Its production is minimal, allowing for the emotional portrayals of the characters to speak loud and in great depth. Armie and Timothee were both brilliant, so good that you can feel that strong lust between them and the utter anguish when that is taken away. It is really captivating to watch for its lengthy runtime.However my favourite scene was when Elio's father speaks to him on the couch, sharing a poignant lesson he'd learnt from his own life after baring witness to his own son's 'close friendship' with Oliver. This echoes into Elio's phone call to Oliver at the film's conclusion. Theres a real sense of desire and heartache. It speaks in a lot of truths, the great loss of innocence and realisations at the hands of a man with such maturity and brilliant-knowingness, and the strength to lust through restricted circumstances.Beautiful film!

This is the kind of movie that stays with you long after watching it. The scenery and aesthetics are more than captivating- they are so beautiful that every shot is worth taking in. This film transported me to Northern Italy in 1983, it truly made me feel like I was there. Another aspect of this movie that is spot on is the soundtrack. The upbeat piano that plays in the background of many of the scenes also creates a feeling of nostalgia for a time that we, as the viewer, may or may not have even experienced. As someone who hadn't seen the trailer, from the beginning of the movie, I was continually wondering if anything would actually happen between Elio and Oliver. The way this movie is filmed and the script given to it builds the tension between the two characters with a lot of care and attention to detail. The performance of Elio by Timothee Chamalet is breathtaking- the viewer can feel his inner struggle with the idea of wanting something so bad, yet wondering whether it's okay to desire what he does. The conversation between Elio and his father at the end is also one that stays with the viewer. It is heart wrenching, and reminds us how important it is to treasure a love like this when we have it, because we don't know how long it will last, or if we will ever come across love like it again. The last few minutes of the film and into the credits is, to me, one of the most heart wrenching parts of the whole movie. "Visions of Gideon" by Sufjan Stevens plays in the background as we see Elio sobbing by the fireplace. Chalamet's performance here is stunning, the emotion in his eyes and his face is so real that the viewer feels it too. My only reservation with this film is that the main character is 17, while Oliver is 24. The age difference here, along with the fact that Elio is a minor, is unsettling. Otherwise, this movie is a must-see.

reviews.review_title: Saw this in Sofia at a festival and it was a packed house!
reviews.content: 'Call Me By Your Name', a film about first love and heartbreak. The cinema where it was showing was packed for a festival that this was a part of. This film is tipped for the Oscars and I can well see why. It is a mature film set in 1983 in Italy and perfectly captures a boy's first love and heartbreak in losing that love. It does it without mushy sentimentality, just truth. The final scene were the credits role and the camera concentrates on the boy's face for 6 minutes as you see the heartbreak set into his features will surely go down as one of the great cinematic moments ever captured on film. In many ways this film is challenging, in that it portrays a love affair between an older man (mid to late 20s) and a teenage boy of 17. But the emotion expressed in such an honest way could apply to anyone gay or straight and audiences are flocking to see it. Both of their lives are messy and it's not straight forward, the older man is quite unlikable and arrogant and it's only as their affair starts that you see the real person blossom. The boy has his first sexual encounter with a girl from his town. But the empathy of his father and acceptance of his son's great love, a love that the father says he never had nor never will, pushes this film beyond mere stereotypes and cliché. The final sequence will leave you emotional, if you have ever had your heart broken at a young age you will see the truth in the boy's face and be grateful that the boy takes his father's message of 'feel the pain, don't bury it, treasure it'. If it wins an Oscar it is well deserved.

Even though it's filmed where I live, I waited a long time to watch this because I usually don't like romantic movies. I have to say it surprised me. Someone would say it's really slow and nothing really happens, but I found it a movie full of heart and care for details. The love story is finally a credible one, where people have quirks and a natural way to get close. It's rare to see a movie where a love story and dialogues don't seem artificial. In every detail you can see that the director and everyone involved wanted to create something special. There is a scene in which they wake up at dawn with an open window, and you can hear exactly what I hear from my window at dawn, the cuckoo and the bells and the light, that made me feel so nostalgic and so immersed in the rainy atmosphere that it was like being there. The speech at the end by Elio's father is beautiful too. It's not rhetoric or banal like most movies do these things when they want to be dramatic, it's absolutely moving and smart and exactly what an amazing parent should be. The delicate love of the parents is one of the nicest ever seen in movies, a true model for every parent out there. The only thing I can say, is that Armie hammer looks a bit too old for 24, I would have preferred a younger-looking actor, but then everything is so well made you don't notice it anymore. Timothee chalamet is sensational in this one, my favorite performance from him till now. For the people saying that everyone can make a nice picture with Italy, maybe it's true, but as someone from here I want to say that most of the movies set in Italy completely miss the atmosphere, making everything seem artificial and fake. Mind you, this happens with many if not most Italian movies too. Not in this one, everything is special because it feels so real and exactly the atmosphere of summer around here.

Secondly, i really liked the subtle way it dealt with topics related to being homosexual, from the discovery of ones sexuality to the choice of (for lack of better words) "staying in the closet or getting out of it" as well as the immense role family support plays in it.
Finally, I liked how organic the ending was, especially considering that the movie does take place in 1983. No tragedy, no exagerations like many movies that represent the community do; just an ending full of feelings and emotions that each and everyone ought to feel at some point in their life.

I sat there crying at the end. Horrible hetero Man leaves that beautiful boy. I would've loved him any day. And then I googled more about the film and apparently the director or whoever said that he would've slowly recovered and eventually started dating his female friend again.That's so stupid. He should at least date another boy and learn from his experience that he should love people regardless of gender, and really try with people. There should be a sequel where he's loving another boy.

Sensible, inspiring and trully emotional.
I was sceptic at the start - but now i think there is more in this movie than you can see at the first look.
It is not exactly a movie about gay's but about true human values
There is a clue: do not miss the last 10 seconds of the movie !!!!
A must see.

I love this movie so much!! i am always looking for a good non-asian? gay film and this was beyond amazing. i really loved elio's and oliver's relationship. it just seemed really deep to me. the actors portrayed elio's and oliver's love for each other spectacularly. great chemistry. the end definitely brought tears to me eyes :'( i really wish oliver could've stayed in italy instead of going and marrying a woman. i'll stop rambling. i highly recommend this movie, especially if you are into sad romance movies like my weird self.

I watched twice and the first time I thought it's kinda disappointing somehow (probably because with English subtitles my understanding was very vague) but this time omg it killed me. This movie isn't about homosexual people but about love (first or lost) that brings you heartbreak. And it kills many people including me, those who had been through a heartbreaking first love ever in life. Brilliant, though I'm not happy with the news of the subsequent movie.

This movie was slow to start, but picked up speed within a reasonable amount of time. I will view "Call Me by Your Name" again in order to see what I might have missed. Initially, it was unclear to me why Oliver (Armie Hammer) was visiting Elio's (Timothee Chalamet's) family for the summer. That became somewhat clearer as the movie progressed.What strikes me is the gentleness of this film. Oliver is sincerely concerned that he has not offended Elio. It is apparent Oliver fears he has crossed a line; but, he has not. The emotion of concern, anxiety and some element of fear is portrayed superbly. There is a level of magnificent innocence and precociousness in Elio that is precious; and, so adolescent! Where Oliver clearly had "dabbled' in his past, this was a whole new experience for Elio.The most impactful moments for me were at the very end, where Elio's father says without saying it that he "knows" Elio had an affair with Oliver. The sheer compassion and love, the absolute absence of judgmentalism, is astonishingly portrayed. Many a gay youth would be greatly blessed to have as a father one who is so understanding; even, somewhat jealous of what his son has experienced with another man. For me, this is not a one view only movie. The music scores are absolutely supreme! Truly GREAT!

The dialogue itself is very subtle, the body language of the characters really say a lot. That is to be said with the brilliant choice of actors! Chalamet and Hammer really know how to express emotions with plain body gestures and it is simply brilliant!

reviews.review_title: Why not use gay actors to portray "gay men in love"?
reviews.content: Agree with another reviewer about the "absolute ZERO chemistry between the two lead roles". Two straight men trying to portray "gay men in love" is absolutely ridiculous. While some found this "immensely enrapturing", I found it to be terse, stereotypical and BORING. Just my take on it. I didn't enjoy this at all.........

I've seen this movie twice, so you don't have to. Despite the beautiful Italian scenery, all the movie's editing is dull and dashed off. The relationship between a way too old man and a way too young boy feels by a 12 yo girl, with particularly disturbing scenes that normalize rape culture. The only good things: the decors, and Timothee Chalamet's playing. Do not see.

Beautiful on every level. Timothée Chalamet is a wonder to behold as Elio Perlman, he and Armie Hammer were perfectly cast and carry this gorgeous movie with immense talent and chemistry with one another. After one viewing this movie quickly shot up the top of my favorites list and after repeated viewings has settled into the top spot.

Call me by your name is a stunning movie with a gorgeous sound track that tries way too hard to be thought provoking.In the movie you see many different scenes that just cut out and leave you to figure out what happened for yourself. They leave out the context. Now I'm not against interpreting scenes but when a movie does that multiple times, again, and again, throughout the whole movie, you get kinda bored of it.The characters were okay. Though elio felt over he top. He was such a dramatic character that really didn't work for me. The way me moves acts and how his personality shifts just wasn't my thing. His dad also was confusing. He was a solid character, and a solid dad figure that was very kind to his son and to others as well. Though his last speech to elio made no sense. It was just too much to make sense of and it fell flat for me.Though maybe it's just because I watched this at 3 am🤷‍♀️

I have seen this movie for the first time when it was released, I have watched I few times again since than. Every time I have a new feeling and interpret it differently.
The truth is that it is a very mature movie, Elio and Oliver have a impossible to ignore age difference, but somehow they make it work with an incredible connection. They deal with the flirt, aproximation and the consummate romance on their own way according to their own age experience. For me, that is the beauty on this movie.
As if it wasn't enough, the landscape and soundtrack are breath taking, I think it is fair to say it is impossible to not fall in love under those conditions.

It is a very well directed film. The movie is just so real, Timothée Chalamet and Armie Hammer have an unequaled chemistry. They build a relationship in a wonderful way, and I think it's also due to the script... It's amazing! They do not rush to present you the beautiful connection between Elio and Oliver, there's definitely a very interesting development. The Italy of 1980 certainly gives a romantic atmosphere to the movie. There are certain things that I didn't like, the cinematography for example. I feel it is very simple, it could have been better. But in general I think it's an amazing coming-of-age film.

"Call me be your name" is a vision of love and truth. Love comes at the first place in the movie. The feeling of desire of the main characters is so pure and gentle which made me pretty satisfied to watch it. It comes naturally, step by step. By exploring the area they live in and spending time for talking about art and life they start getting to know each other. It works like a binder, but they're not sure what every and each of them really wants. There's a time when they did and that's what really matter about their relationship. It had better to be remembered about times the plot takes place - it's 80s and it's a hard period for an unconventional love. The end of the movie is sorrowful and tough for, I think, both of them. Oliver is older and seems to get used to reality of the world he lives in, but he still has a hope. On the other hand, Elio is much younger and inexperienced. He's full of hope as well, but his hope is related with naiveness what turns out exacatly at the end. "Call me by your name" is an one of these movies which deeply moved by its form and gentleness. The history of those men urge me to think straight, but also remember who we really are. I couldn't forget about the soundtrack which fits as a glove to the movie. The film director - Luca Guadagnino - has done a great job and so have the actors. Thank you for such a poignant piece of art!

reviews.review_title: Best acting I've seen in a while
reviews.content: This movie is a masterpiece. It's visually spectacular and the actors are amazing. Timothée Chalamet is a gem; i don't think i've ever seen an actor be so good at acting tormented, it just felt so real. The soundtrack is also amazing, it makes you even more invested and emotional watching the movie. Absolutely worth a watch!

For a person who easily dives into a movie, this film is just beautifully magnificently brutal. I enjoyed by each and every minute of it, I built up feelings and submerged in it, and as the story unfolds, mess is my emotion, a complete mess.In my knowledge, this is an independent film then it becomes recognized worldwide with positive enthusiasm which is also why, this coming-of-age/romance is a must watch film along with its beautiful lines and things to ponder about the mystery of love :)It was just the perfect drama to end the year.

This is one of the most beautiful movies I've ever seen in my life. Not only is the acting just brilliant but the cinematography is just on another level, it's outstanding. There are not enough words to express how much I love this movie. I cried like a baby at the end of the movie, and it has left an impression on me.

Ok. I dealt with the flies. The many, many flies (EVEN IN WINTER BY A FIRE). It reminded me those old "Save the Children" ads, but I reeled myself back in (at first).I enjoyed the scenery and waited like a pet waits for its owner to fill up her bowl. I hear it. I see it. I know it's coming! I'm ready for this romance!I was open minded about the fact that the main character looks 15, squirrelly and is kind of a jerk. I appreciated the hippy academic parents and stabs at a cool soundtrack. I LOVE Italy...30 years later...
But um. Oh. Awkward. Is this...romance?
And WTF happened with Marcy???! Was that necessary? Go play with your peach or apple pie and leave that girl alone! This made me angry. And there was no turning back.Who does that? Even if we are chalking this up to a "summer fling," how the hell am I expected to give two sh-ts about the main character after he completely tosses her aside like trash. ESPECIALLY, when he pursued HER and she even told him she was afraid of getting hurt. Yea. Cool. She's the bigger person, approaches him and then they're "friends forever"...but I would have preferred some actual Italian passion at that moment. Like screw.you.dude. Aaaannnd he could care less.One person's love isn't better or more important than another's. Just because you're in love doesn't mean you have to be an ass to someone else. That Surfjan song could've easy been playing in her mind.No thanks!
I cried ... they make it too good. Olio and Oliver deliver the feelings ... I cannot say much :-(
Real masterpiece. The most sad thing about it is that i can not give more than 10 points.

reviews.review_title: Sexist, pretentious and thoroughly underwhelming slop.
reviews.content:
This movie will be loved by gay men and fans of patriarchal intellectualism, the lead character is arrogant, narcissistic and shallow to the core, as indeed are many of the other male characters, the love of the male seems to be the main thrust of the film, while female characters are dismissed generally as pathetic male worshipping puppies, in one scene the men are talking about the opportunity for Timothee Chalamets character to have sex with a your female, and of course he could have her whenever he wanted, though when an enquiry from the mother about the discussion she overhears but who is not present at the table but engaged in gardening, and not involved in the conversation, she is summarily dismissed by the male party when they change the subject, as if a mother in such a free spirited community would be somehow be shocked by the thought of her son engaging in a sexual relationship, as a man I found this whole scene quite demeaning to women, as was the general attitude to female roles in the movie, without one single strong female character throughout.
I found the whole film shallow and its presentation of male intellectualism and demigod worshipping by even shallower female characters unbelievably sexist and demeaning, I'm amazed that this is presented as a love story, the lead character, rather than a bohemian, intellectual, romantic, is just a self absorbed, narcissistic waster in love with his own self importance, there's nothing to love about him at all.
I cannot find anything to recommend this completely wasted opportunity. its shallow and sexist and, like its lead character, in love with its own self importance, with a subliminal message to women that you are only there to worship the men and do the chores, woeful.
After you watched the movie, that magical sadness will stand with you maybe more than a few days. Be ready for that. Probably the best movie in my life.
It was boring from the start to the end. If my life was on watching this nonsense again I'd rather to die
I've never seen a worse movie. Boring, slow, bad caracters, bad acting, i supose it is for adolescent in crises??! Unwatchable!

Call Me by Your Name is beautiful in every way. I've never written a review here before, but if anyone is on the fence about watching, this is a movie you must see. It's beautifully written, directed, everything. Very emotional.

I finally saw this movie after listening to the hype for years. As a gay man, I came away with the feeling, okay, they made a long pretty movie about first heartbreak. Yawn. Elio will get over it, everyone gay or straight gets over that first unbearable soul crushing (in this case peach crushing) disappointment. Oliver will get married and may or may not live happily ever after, depending on whether or not he is caught cheating on his wife with some pubescent lad he has decided to call by his name. There was too much here that for me didn't ring true. Elio wasn't particularly likeable. I had the feeling that his intelligence and talent were necessary in order that Oliver not come across as borderline pedophile. By the same token, I found Oliver downright irritating, which meant, for me, that Elio "fell in love" with a smokin' bod, not a warm desirable personality. Hah. Been there, done that. Finally, Elio's father's lecture at the end seemed a little too neat and clean a wrap up. (Remember, fiction must be truer to life than life!) And as for Timothée Chalamet's tearful closeup as the credits rolled? I wanted to say, listen honey, as soon as that snow melts, you get your bony butt out there and find someone else to fall in love with! (So what with all my kvetching, why did I give the movie 5 stars? Hey, long pretty movie about gay heartbreak, I'm required by law to at least semi like it!)

I had pretty high expectations going into this movie. Expectations that were, unfortunately, not met. It is a love story about a man and a boy. And that's pretty much all there's to it. In this relationship, Oliver's (Arnie Hammer) didn't feel genuine for just one moment. I'm not sure if his acting or the script is to blame for that. Apart from this seemingly one-sided love story, there's not much to this movie. There are some other characters, but their roles have very little impact.
The only things that are preventing this movie from being dead boring are Timothée Chalamets incredible performance, and the music score. But mostly Chalamets acting. His performance is the only things that pulled me through this movie, and with only 22 years old, he is one to watch.

reviews.review_title: No words can describe..... (well not many)
reviews.content:
There is that kind of love that is so strong and liberating, that once it stops.. 
your heart gets scarred for life. Most of us know what it feels like and never forgot about it...This story will make you feel it all over again.Now stop reading this and go see this movie!

I had never written a review before, but after watching this movie i just felt the necessity, so i am sorry for my not so good english. I don´t know where to start, but i should say that is one of the best romantic stories i have ever seen. I don´t know what adjectives should i use to describe this, it is so sensual, erotic and beatiful. The cinematography is gorgeous, with some beatiful landscapes of Italy (and also a lot of culture!). The sondtrack is really great and worth listening more than once, including the Sufjan Steven´s songs. What can i say about the acting? Timothee Chalamet was just perfect as Elio, he is outstanding and is probably getting many awards; i can´t wait to see him in other movies. Armie Hammer as Oliver was great too! They both have excellent chemistry and the dialogues between them are perfect. I haven´t read the book yet but Luca Guadagnino made an excellent job, and i am sure that is greatly adapted. What i liked the most about this film is that it doesn´t bring up the typical homophobia or AIDS plot, is just the romantic story we deserved, and every single minute is worth the watch. It will probably become a classic in the future. I won´t spoil the ending, but i gotta say that is just so overwhelming and heartbreaking at the same time. You definitely have to watch this movie as soon as possible. Oh, by the way, there is a scene involving a peach that you probably heard about before, it is as perfect as you can expect and it could get the entire film the awards it deserves.

reviews.review_title: Shame on all of your screening team..
reviews.content: The screening crew decided that miracle words as " Jews" and "Gays", could automatically open door for OSCAR nominee and another rewards..Hope in Oscar academy enough mentally strong people, which not approve artificial Italian-Jewish story with cheap scenario, cameraman job, sound and other mistakes... Please take out this scrap - from cinema watchers. Shame on all of your screening team..

I am sorry to dry somebodys well-earned tears but I didn't find this especially touching. I usually like these artsy gayfilms e.g Maurice, Brideshead, Brokeback Mountain etc. but this is not very good on portraying characters. The actors all look like passive onlookers not active partisipants on their own life! This is especially true on character of Oliver. We really don't know anything about him. His past, his hopes, dreams or his imner feelings. What makes him tick?
 And Elio. He is just a sullen teenager with a boring life. Walks around in his boxers looking for something. Usually at 17 you know If you are homo or hetero or something in between. Besides, in 1983 guys were wearing briefs.
 And this peach scene... Every man knows that you can not do this to a peach. You only end up with sticky mush. Unless you have a very small penis - the size of a matchstick. And why is Oliver eating the peach? Is this one way of saying I Love Thee Always? There are more subtle ways of saying that. Now it is something out of Ed Wood,jr's imagination. 
 These two lovers are never actually in love. They are just having sex and fooling around. Only little tenderness but mostly Oliver is giving Elio a cold shoulder. And he is sometimes even putting him down, like in the interrupted oral sex scene. I hope he is treating his girlfriend better or their marriage won't last.
 It is hard to find the last crying scene touching. What is Elio missing? His cold-hearted lover or his virginity? Or his lovely peach? Words of his father are good but they belong to a different movie, where we end up caring about the characters.
 One thing that could have made this movie is If they had the balls to make Elio a 15 year old. Boys of that age usually try everything for a size, including peaches. But had they done it, the cryers would start roaring and crucifying everybody connected with this film. That is how we have evolved, sadly.

Actually, I regret to read the book before watching this. I can't stopping compare it to the book involuntary. When I watching this film, I thought it's newness and agreeable sometimes, but it could disillusion me sometimes. I'm totally a fan of the book, and I think it's perfect and rated it full score. The scene that most surprised me is their flirting by playing piano. I don't really know classic music, so I can't imagine that scene when I read it. And another scene I loved is the final scene: Elio stared at the fire and wept. And I also love the scene that Elio expressed his love to Oliver. Anyway, Timothée has really good acting skill, and I truly wish he can win the Oscar. I think the directing is pretty good, but what dissatisfied me is the screenplay. Actually, my favorite scene is gone, the scene that Elio gave Oliver a book as a gift. For you in silence. But I really enjoyed the soundtrack, although it didn't be nominated for the Golden Globe.
Defiantly my favourite film from 2017 and would recommend anyone to I watch it.

This movie left me with out words; I've never been so blown away by a movie. Call Me By Your Name might be the best movie I've ever seen. Everything about it is pitch perfect; I love the characters, I love the area they are in and would love to go there, the cinematography is perfect, and the directing is on a god-like level. This movie is a masterpiece, it will go down as one of the greatest romances ever. Timothee Chalamet gives one of the best performances I've ever seen in my life and I just love him. Watch this movie and you will not be let down, it is beautiful.

"Call Me By Your Name" came out in 2017, as one the latest gay movie, and I would say it is the most non-gay movie that I have ever seen in this category. This summer romance between teenager Elio and grown up Oliver happens so smooth, beautiful, and relax. When thousands of movies is about straight teenagers' adolescence experience, "Call Me By Your Name" portrays the perfect childhood of Elio. Comparing to Brokeback Mountain, this movie focus more on the happiness to the struggle. In fact, the sweetness and romance of this movie redefine the concept of gay movie, since gay movie always focus on the pressure of the outside world and love between the two. The fact that Elio lives in open minded family that supports his feelings is surprisingly different from other gay movies. The presence of "Call Me By Your Name" also proves that people nowadays have a new level of understanding or homosexual relationship, and proves that it be just relax and sweet as any other relationship. Oliver and Elio is beyond sexulity, age, and experience, and significantly indicates that love is above everything. Even though Oliver eventually leaves Elio and gets married, this experience is still lasting forever,

This film is my best movie last year. I can't help crying when I saw last scene. very pure sensuality and emotion. We can know character's feeling through there's eyes. They are very good acting. We can see beautiful view of north Italy. I highly recommend this movie if you want to feel sorrowful.

reviews.review_title: What do you try to sell and tell me?
reviews.content: Even if you can relate to the topic of a short romance u had in your youth, which is - and I take a wild guess here - plausible, you should not look over the fact that Oliver (24 yrs old) is, in fact, having a sexual relationship with a teen of 17 yrs....i mean....and it´s not even romantic in the least because Oliver is an eel and so he´s kinda disgusting. What is going on? And wtf are the parents thinking? Like: "Oh look, our teenage-son has sexual intercourse with my assistant student. Isn´t that romantic!? I wish I was that brave in my youth." That is not romantic, it´s painful to watch. This movie IS PAIN!Nice camera work and cinematography though.

I enjoyed the movie, but found myself unmoved by it. I am a gay man, and cried in real life at the loss of a love as a young man, similarly to the way Timothee Chalamet does at the end of the movie. When the lights came up, the friend I saw it with, also gay, was in tears. For him, the movie dredged up powerful emotions connected to similar events from his life. So what didn't work for me?As the movie progressed, I found the permission granted to grad student Oliver by Elio's parents to be just too precious to be believed. Everything seems to conspire to relieve Oliver of responsibility for indulging his passion for a vulnerable younger man, including Elio taking the first (and several) overt courtship steps. The story seemed to be clumsily and observably removing any potentially taboo elements in order to give Oliver permission for the romance. By doing so, it flattened the tension for me, and reduced the romance to a cliché. Even though the age of consent is lower in Italy, Elio is depicted with all the badges of minority; a student, living with his parents, inexperienced in his feelings toward men. Oliver is older, practiced at seduction with women at least, a grad student/ guest in the home. So a taboo relationship, or at least some unethical guest behavior is set up. But the parents' permission, broadcast long before the "father-son" talk scene, removes all the gates, flattening any dramatic tension. So the relationship could have been between two 17 year olds, or two 24 year olds, without the feint at taboo. I found myself laughing at the story as it unfolded. It wants to be both naughty and PC at the same time. Similarly to how I thought about "Carol" with Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara after seeing it; I wondered if this wasn't a same-sex romance and otherwise showed me two characters dealing with love and loss, would I care about these characters? Or I they only interesting because of the still-novel twist of same-sex love in a mainstream movie? On that score, I found Timothee Chalamet to be a good actor, channeling desire and loss, but Elio is not that interesting a character. And both Armie Hammer and Oliver struck me a pieces of preppie furniture with no inner life detectable.Finally, even Michael Schulberg's father-son talk at the end struck me as the ending of an afterschool special or "a very special episode of Blossom." Of course, I wish someone had spoken to me that way when I was a teenager. maybe I'm resentful no one did. But I'm back to the word "precious".  The Italian scenery was lovely, however.

This story was so well told. It was sensual, loving, true to life. I would love to ee a sequel where Oliver and Elio reunite and Oliver did not get married. There is so much potential for an even stronger love story. We want to see them together, I have watched this movie so many times. I cry every time.

A beautiful love story set in the charming Italian summer becomes a deeply moving film that is also incredibly ecstatic visually. Amazing acting by Timothee Chalamet and Armie Hammer and beautiful soundtrack by Sufjan Stevens make this coming of age/romantic drama even more worthy of watching.
For me, I love drama, this movie is like a paradise that I was let go of

This movie has an unforgettable atmosphere. Not only it touches on the awkwardness and absurdity of love, but it also reveals the sadness of it. Perfection and imperfection hand in hand. One of the best movies made in 2017. Simply beautiful and touching.

Hated this movie. Extremely boring, weak & annoying characters. Hated it

I had skipped over this title a few times but one night i decided to give it a go.

I have read the book and I do love the how they adapted it to film and being true to the story. I highly recommend.
This is the best love story in the last 5 years. I LOVE THIS MOVIE!!!!

Honestly before watching this film I didn't have much great expectations expecting not to like or enjoy it, however I must say this film so far is defiantly my most loved one which is rather shocking despite the fact I'm the type of person to like action and comedy films.I wanted to start by saying how amazing the cinematography in this film is, astonishing shots in Northern Italy really do bring it to life, More so the film used the same 35mm lens throughout the entire film as if representative of the human eye. reviews.review_title: "Because he was he, because I was I"
reviews.content:
I heard about 'Call Me By Your Name' two years ago, when it was making its rounds at the festivals, garnering some serious praise. For some reason, though, I never watched it. Until now. And all I have to say, is I wish I would have seen it sooner.This film is a near masterpiece. It's set pieces, the cinematography, the acting, the soundtrack, the dialogue - it all pours together to make you feel not like you are watching it, but like you are living it. Feeling it. It seems less as if you are watching Elio and Oliver, and more as if you are Elio and Oliver. You feel all the emotions they are feeling. You go through this exploration with them, through this deep, passionate, all too short love affair, with them. And you experience it all as if you were feeling it yourself.The pacing and structure of this film is so far unlike "the norm" and I believe that is why it feels so real, and so surreal at the same time. Things move slowly and then quickly - because for Elio and Oliver, their relationship froze the world around them, but at the same time, was over before it truly began.I believe the third act of this film is without flaw. We finally witness the two lovers embrace who they are, and are able to have their own getaway together, a part of the film which actually breezes by. I think the small amount of footage we actually get from their trip is resembling of how fleeting it feels to them. The final act contains 5 of the most emotional and heart wrenching scenes I have seen in recent memory.The first is Elio and Oliver's goodbye.
There is really no dialogue here, and no need for it. Their embrace conveys all their emotions. And when Oliver goes to walk away and Elio pulls him in, it perfectly communicates his desire to hold on to what they have.
The second is when Elio calls and asks his mother to pick him up, and on their car ride home there is no dialogue, not even music, just the sound of the road. Yet the emotion screams in this simple scene. A heartbroken boy fighting back tears, and his mother consoles him with a simple stretched out hand.
The third is when Elio arrives home and speaks to his father. Michael Stuhlbarg delivers the best supporting cast monologue of 2017. He subtly informs Elio he knows about his relationship with Oliver and that he is thankful his son could experience such emotions and such friendship. He then confides in his son that he, too once had someone to call him by his name, but was too scared, and unable to act on his feelings. He then encourages his son not to kill his pain, because in doing so, it would kill the joy he also felt.
The fourth is after a time jump where it fast forwards to a winter day, and Elio receives a phone call from Oliver.
Oliver calls Elio to break the news that he has been engaged. And you can hear the heartbreak in his voice. Elio suspects this is why Oliver calls, but Oliver sounds devastated to have to tell him this. "Elio. Elio, Elio, Elio, Elio" whispers Elio. And after a long pause Oliver whispers back "Oliver..... I remember everything."
The fifth and most gut wrenching scene is also the final scene of the film.
As soon as their conversation ends, Elio walks into the dining room and squats by the fire. He stares blankly into the flames - as Visions of Gideon by Sufjan Stevens plays in the background - with tears forming in his eyes.
He stays this way as the end title card appears. He remains unmoved, except to wipe his tears away, as his family prepares for dinner. The lyrics "I have loved you for the last time" "was it a video? was it a video?" Repeat themselves. You can all but see Elio replaying every encounter, every laugh, every embrace, every memory he had with Oliver. As a fly lands on him, he does not break his gaze, in this very moment, you are Elio, and you truly feel his pain. Timothée Chalamet is agonizingly perfect in this sequence.In conclusion, I loved this film. And perhaps my favorite thing about it is that I assumed it was a movie about love, or about a secret affair, I kept waiting for something to go wrong, for them to be found by Elio's parents. But I was wrong. This film is not about love, but about heartbreak, and you don't even see it coming until the last 25 minutes. And in those last 25 minutes there is enough emotion to last an entire lifetime of films.
The most pathetic movie i have ever watched. the storyline is average and watching this movie is a very boring experience.

reviews.review_title: Admiration, Envy and Lust leading to Love for an by anyone... of any age, sex, etc.
reviews.content: Admiration, Envy and Lust leading to Love for an by anyone... of any age, sex, etc. The movie is raw with uncomfortable conversations that I wish were a little more developed in this movie. But then again, they are portraying a young 17 year old boy. The acting is incredible along with the story and visual environment and scenes. Very natural and raw. But the dialogue could have been more developed. I think they did go swimming a little too often and not leaving space for thought out dialogue. From experiencing Italy as a resident, we didn't go swimming that often and seem so bored in childhood and adulthood. The movie is still very close to a 10 though.

reviews.review_title: Will cinema ever outgrow this obsession?
reviews.content: Oh look another sex-packed story full of affectations and wasted gorgeous cinematography. Like Elio tells Oliver at one point "maybe it made sense when you wrote it." It's rich, maybe too rich. Or shall I say healthy? Like baby feet. It made me feel ill and atrophied. That and devoid of contrast. It's like the peach Elio molests. Ripe and festering. Winter slightly soothed the disease but it failed to wash it away.

This is the kind of film you should watch with your eyes. It wins over you with the atmosphere that you want to dive into and dissolve in - an Italian village, where midday is hot and nighttime brings sea breezes, while all you do is have your breakfast in the garden, read poetry and sometimes communicate with other people who are as well smart and beautiful.Here comes love. Love - in this case - not desperate and torturing, but light and beautiful. Beautiful. I think this is the key word to describe the film. The plot, however, does not contain anything you can't predict, so had it not been for the gay, we would even call it hackneyed. However, as I have said before, the visual and acting part are marvelous. If you are tired from your life, this may be a great choice to escape from it all.I would not recommend to watch the film neither with homophobic people, nor with children or teenagers who are unable to perceive erotic scenes adequately. These two types would definitely spoil your experience. To everyone else - wish you to enjoy Timotheé Chalamet's Italian and good luck!

I feel as though I have definitely wasted two and a half hours of my day watching this film. The story was extremely slow and disengaging. As someone who affiliates with the LGBT community, I can say that this film was pretty much just a gay erotica. There was hardly any worth while character building and by the end of it I felt like I hardly knew the characters. The movie was mostly about the sexual relationship between a 17 year old boy and a middle aged man maybe in his 30's. Romantic fluffy scenes were short, awkward and felt forced. There was little worthwhile plot to it. 
The whole movie left me questioning how much longer there was left and the only part I enjoyed was the end, not just because it meant the movie was over but because it gave us the most amount of plot we'd been given throughout the whole thing. The ending would've been better in the middle of the movie and based it off of there. 
I felt very bad for the girls in the movie who had been lead on.
Could've done a lot more in the time it took to watch this movie, but felt like I couldn't bail on my friends, they didn't like it either I found out at the end. I also feel like it wasn't a very good interpretation of gay characters especially with the 0 dysphoria even though the movie was supposed to be about finding himself. Thought it might be good because of the extremely high ratings, very very disappointed.

Call Me By Your Name directed by Luca Guadagnino was a very interesting film to me. The general plot is that Oliver (Armie Hammer) goes to stay at a northern Italian villa owned by professor Perlman (Michael Stuhlbarg) and his wife Annella (Amira Casar) to work on his doctorate for the summer. While he is there, he meets Elio (Timothée Chalamet), the 17 year old son of Mr. & Mrs. Perlman. At the beginning, Elio isn't very fond of Oliver and finds him 'arrogant', but soon comes to find that his initial dislike for Oliver is rooted in something much more complex; something that both Elio and Oliver struggle to admit. The settings are completely gorgeous. I loved the 'feel' of their sets for northern Italy, and it has actually inspired me to potentially visit there some day. There's just something about their quiet and secluded town that I found extremely beautiful.The acting and script were decent, sometimes average. I wouldn't say the film's acting is horrible, but I wouldn't call it superb either. However, I felt the chemistry and emotion was there when it counted. I thought Timothee Chalamet as Elio was the stand-out performance, and he really made the film for me. Also, this film didn't need superb acting in order to for it to capture my attention. Once I started watching the film, I fell in love with the characters, regardless of acting. If it was BAD acting, THEN I wouldn't be able to get over it. But at the same time, there are so many things in acting, that I would say it is more of the verbal acting that was average, where as the facial expressions, body movement, pacing, etc. was all very good, and it kept me interested in the two main characters, Elio and Oliver.There wasn't much to the plot ... two men, exploring their sexuality under a shroud of secrecy. I don't think this movie is really one you watch for an intriguing and complex plotline ... it's pretty straight forward, and it's more about the development of a relationship as it pertains to its characters rather than the development of its characters in relation to its plot. I don't know if that really makes sense ... for example, instead of the movie being focused on developing characters independently, this film felt as though we were meant to focus on the growth of the relationship wherein the characters developed with one another. I felt like that direction was correct. It's not like there is NO character development, just that it's not the main focus of the film. Maybe some of you consider their relationship as the plot, which is true, so hopefully you can still understand me. Overall, I really liked the film. To the point where I shed a single tear - I hardly ever cry, and not even concerning just movies, but life in general. I felt a lot for these characters, especially for Elio. If I wanted to rate the film personally, I would give it a 9/10. But I wanted to rate it somewhat objectively. I read some of the other reviews, and a lot of people didn't really like it. I can understand that. If you don't feel a connection between Elio and Oliver, I don't think you will like the film that much. But if you can find that connection, and if you enjoy looking into the complexities of intimacy and sexuality, you will probably enjoy this film. I already plan to see it again. It reminded me of Maurice, the novel by E.M Forster, which I adore. This movie is definitely going to be one that I will re-watch over and over again.

The movie is so flat. I watched the first hour and get bored all along. Thimothée doesn't play well. The storyline is slow and the characters are so empty. I don't get why people are so in love with this movie. It hasn't any charm. And the love romance between the main characters is imaginary.

Don't believe the hype. After all the "best film ever made/masterpiece/10 out of 10/perfection" reviews I cannot tell you how disappointed I was. Given the 45 minute drive each way to find a cinema playing this, that's a total of 4 hours of my life I cannot get back.If you've seen more than three art house films (all of which will be better than this) you'll be bored out of your mind. The only people who would give this a 10/10 would be "I've just seen my first art house film" newbs, the director's parents, or the director himself, Luca Gaudagnino, who I'm sure spent every moment between takes practising his Oscar acceptance speech. Pretentious (another reviewer here nailed it - "smug and self congratulatory"), dull, aimless, confused, no stakes, no conflict, no structure... I could go on. And I will.The director was so painfully in awe of how avant garde his film was - yet it really wasn't. All this talk of how "sensual" and "sumptuous" the film was - it's just not there. It really isn't. So the kid jizzed into a peach. Is that it? American Pie did that fifteen years ago, and it wasn't pretending to be avant garde.There is an expression in poker - don't fall in love with your cards - meaning, don't fall so in love with how amazing you think your hand is that you stop paying attention to what the other players have. And in this case the director fell so in love with his film he forgot to think of the audience, and crafting well turned story points for them.Zero chemistry between the two male leads - Armie looked nervous as hell and the kid was dull. The only person I cared about was the female love interest, played by Esther Garrel - excellent acting on her part. Another classic rookie mistake - not knowing when to end! There were three different endings. And this was after a 5 minute eulogy on heartbreak from the father, who made the same point in about 6 different ways - WE GET IT, "feel the pain of heartbreak". I could see Luca behind the lens at this point, mouthing out the words to his Oscar speech.Speaking of the parents - they were cool with this? "Oh hey Armie Hammer, giant late 20s man staying in our house in a professional context... please have our tiny 17 year old son as your sexual plaything for the summer". What?If this was indeed an Imdb campaign to hype up the score and sell tickets, please think about the people on the other end - who gave up hours of their precious life to have you take to their brain cells with a rubber mallet.If you want "sumptuous" and "sensual" go eat a mango. It'll save you fifteen bucks.

If I could, I would give this movie 10000 out of ten. Every time I see it I love it even more. The acting is sublime, the screenplay is so well written, it is beautifully shot and the production design is just flawless. It is so real, so sincere and so pure. Guadagnino has this beautiful way of conveying feelings and making them so honest, with every movie I watch by him, I become more and more of a fan, and this movie definitely is the top of the Guadagnino films I've watched. It's simply majestic.

Call Be My Your Name I the best gay movie of all time. It didn't have any hurtful stereotypes. It didn't over emphasize that the characters were gay. It wasn't overdone or unbelievable. It was real. Just two people in love played by AMAZING actors that made you feel every single emotion played on screen. Can't wait for the sequel!

I just finished watching this 10 minutes ago and I'm still crying. Definetly the best movie ever created. The raw emotion and extremely realistic storyline are unparalleled and I'm so happy that Sony Pictures made this movie because we need more REAL films about gay relationships and people instead of fabricated and stereotypical crap.

reviews.review_title: Left me with an unexplainable feeling
reviews.content: Call Me by Your Name is one of those films that will leave you wanted to wtch it again right away. Let's begin with the directing of this film. Luca Guadagnino shows us the sensual beauty of the Italian landscape and through his visuals of Elio and Oliver shows us all true love. For me, CMbYN reminds me of first love and exploring and discovering your partner. As many have said this isn't a gay love story, rather a love story. When it comes to coming of age films, this is the top of the line. Films like "Boyhood" many can connect with, but not all. CMbYN is a coming of age movie that we can all connect with. It reminds of us of our first love and those feelings that you never want to leave, and the pain that you feel when they do. It brings on the emotion of knowing that you couldn't feel so unhappy if you had not been so happy, showing us true emotion. Call Me by Your Name is a film that will stick with my for a long time and I will think of it everyday as I have already since I saw it days ago.

The first problem is Armie Hammer. Although he has really good body and sexy voice, he didn't know how to make the best of them. It is awkward to watch he smiling during serious dialog. His underperformance lessend the chemistry between the two protagonists. In contrast, Timothée Chalamet, the cast of Elio, is stunning. He brought the character alive and perfectly interacted with other casts.There are also problems with the scripts. Several important plots were crossed off in this film, such as, the most crucial and conspicuous one, the peach eating scene. Even if I didn't read the novel, I would consider this plot indispensable, for it signifies the sublimation of the relation between Elio and Oliver. Without this scene, it is like that the film failed to reach the vertex while it was supposed to.Nevertheless, the file itself is still brilliant and touching by successfully protraying the beautiful Italian countryside and the minutia of the life of a 17 boy falling in love the first time in his life.

This movie is bound to resonate with many young people struggling with adolescent crushes and identity questions--as well as with adults reflecting on their own identity development.Timothy Chalamet is convincing, with androgynous charm that melds innocence and yearning and passionate intensity. Setting aside the vapid expectation that a movie directly correspond to a book, I think we can overlook the apparent age discrepancy between Armie Hammer and the character he portrays. Hammer's more mature Oliver suits and shapes the movie. And he does it well, with the kind of insouciant regard for young Ellio that might be expected for an adult indulging himself in a ripe peach or an unexpected tryst with a young man slightly more than half his age.Some bits stand out. Would that we all had fathers like Ellio's, played by the estimable Michael Stuhlbarg, who give us room to explore our identities without judgement. Yet it cannot be overlooked that Ellio's identity struggle, his fear of being caught, his yearning to be with (and belong to) Oliver happens despite his father's calm acceptance. Perhaps we are to learn that the deep existential angst of adolescence is inevitable, even if we have supportive families--though how much harder it would have been had Ellio's father responded with rage and violence, as so many young people continue to experience.It is in this context of Ellio's adolescent ego development that the title of the movie raises complex questions. What are we to make of such a highly intelligent adult, with his own well-established identity, who tells his young lover to "call me by your name"? Is Oliver seeking to reclaim some part of his own youthful identity by switching identities? Or is he knowingly stroking the younger man's natural predisposition to see himself at the center of the universe? Perhaps both. Either way, life--and ego development--go on for Ellio, and the pain of Oliver's ultimate betrothal to a woman marks an inflection point in his path to adulthood.

Are you kidding??? What is all the hoopla about??? This movie was horrible! After decades of demonizing, hate mongering, smearing and the most vicious negative stereotypes by the movie industry I'm all for positive LGBT portrayals but this was just a terrible movie in every objective sense. The acting by Armie Hammer (Oliver) was awful, wooden, absolutely Shatner-like. Plot and character development were virtually non-existent. The two protagonists were thrown together arbitrarily and for no apparent reason just start acting awkwardly and then for some reason pawing at each other. I never for a moment bought into the attraction between the two. You could see them acting a mile away. I literally could not sit thru the whole movie. This is in direct contrast to Being 17, the epitome of this genre. The photography was simply sublime. The character development was lovingly drawn out in exquisite detail - Thomas' love of the mountains and his defensive loneliness, Damien's scholastic ambition and his growing feelings for Thomas. You could feel the tension and attraction developing naturally between the two. The progression of their relationship made perfect sense. It deserved many more awards.

Omg. Why this movie is so greatly rated is Beyond me. The writing is soooo poor. Acting is average. The whole movie has this "student project" feel. You barely meet the characters. Even the two guys really. It's not always predictable how they'd behave. Sometimes a main character is arrogant. The other times he's vulnerable. Every scene. Every line. Every joke even is totally generic and almost as if they're by a book. Again, for student. All the songs are cheesy. Expected much more of this movie. Though just because of the great ratings.

reviews.review_title: One of the most bring and worst movies
reviews.content: This is just a waste of time. I can't think of a movie more boring.

reviews.review_title: A good film, but the book is better.
reviews.content: I read the book not long after it became popular and loved it, so obviously I decided to watch the film. Timotheé Chamalet's phenomenal acting was with certainly the best part; with his amazing expressions and wow-factor delivery I loved every bit of it. Armie Hammer on the other, was not. He was absolutely the wrong actor, mostly it just bugged me he was way too old for the part of Oliver. I also read somewhere that he refused to do certain explicit scenes and I think in this kind of film where the main plot point is romance.. you kinda need it? I think a better actor (and one that looked the part) would've done a better job overall.I was surprised they kept a certain scene in - if you've seen it you know what I'm talking about - since it didn't add anything really to either the book or film (except a lot of reviews from people who were creeped out) but I guess well done to Timotheé for not backing out.Cinematography, gorgeous. Editing, good.Overall a good film, but not one to watch with your parents.

The first 40 minutes of this very slow paced flick were interesting enough but then everything began to suck. Elio's behavior especially becomes quite ridiculous. Notably nearly all character start to smoke as if they were in long commercial for the tobacco industry, which have most probably provide half of the movie's budget following a common sponsorship practice.

When I first watch this movie it was hard for me to understand and I fast forward through most of it. Then eventually I watch it again and it really hit me, the relationship these boys had. I couldn't help but cry that it was not a happy ending. The way the music and the directing took place just made you feel like you were a bystander to their relationship.

The movie explains both their characters in very subtle details. Could not help the tears. It really touched me. Light words but so powerful and direct. I wish everyone can love like they do. I could not sleep after watching this movie. It is such a masterpiece. It is not real and so touching, almost little bit like a documentary. The story tells how it is. It is not like NOTE BOOK, it is a different romantic. If you liked movie HER, you would like this one even more. I could not move for minutes after watching it...... it TOUCHED me so deeply.

Call Me By Your Name was a film that I've had no idea about. Everybody talked about the movie this year, and I just wasn't interested to see this movie because of this. But now that I've watched this movie, I see why it caught so much attention.
I fell in love with it.
I fell in love with the main character Elio. He played the piano, his behavior was so fun to watch, and everything that he talked about was so smart. All of these traits made him an interesting character, a character worth to watch.
As much as I adored his personality , I fell in love with his development throughout the movie also. Timothee Chalamet's performance was stunning. As a teenager that discovered himself and his sexual desires, Timothee showed the struggles of growing up and learning about 
his own personality powerfully. His break down because of the shame he felt, the peach scene (and his conversation with Oliver afterwards), and him crying at the end... All of his emotions were so genuine and real that he made me feel the same way as he did.
(Also his chemistry with Oliver was so good- the sex scenes had a moving dynamism that we don't usually see in love movies so often, and the intensity of the emotions that they managed to convey had a big impact on the success of the movie in my opinion)
There weren't several set designs, rather the scenes were shot simply. From only one angle, I saw what I had to, and the simplicity with the angles made the character's performances stand out .
I think the movie was both emotional and moving. It was real, bittersweet and genuine. It wasn't like a fairytale, it was like a mirror of life, and the way that it showed us the truths about life was so powerful. All of the cast, not only Timothee, had stunning performances that made all of the characters so unique. Everything was just as it should have been, and I just questioned myself about the reason that I've always postponed to watch this movie.

One of those movies that stays in your head a while after watching it. Loved it!! Have been trying to find a similar film to watch but honestly, nothing might come close. Happy for any recommendations. Hope I will get to watch something like this one day again!

I was really looking forward to seeing this movie ever since I saw the trailer last year. I don't usually get too excited for movies these days, because most of them end up being a disappointment. Call Me by Your Name though was absolutely great, and lived up to my expectations. I would definitely recommend this movie.

Found this on Netflix on a lazy Sunday. After reading the reviews here on IMDb, I needed to give this movie a shot.This took me back so many years. It made me remember the time when I felt something like this in my younger years - the forbidden love. I couldn't help myself but to feel lost, confused, and in love. The ending destroyed me.If you want to know what love feels like, watch this masterpiece. You will get a hint.

I watched this movie tonight. It may difficult to say it is a totally good movie, but the director really tells us a good story...in a right way. The director changed the end of the story, although they are still separated. But I really like this new ending, at least Eliot still has his father and the family. I feel empty after the movie. In Chinese, we called 'You Qing Ren Zhong Cheng Juan Shu', which means wish all well, jack shall have Jill.Best wishes, to all of us!!

This film was not my favorite. I hated how Incredibly glorified they made Europe look, and how Élio (Timothee Chalamet) was quite an unrealistic teenager. I found Élio rather annoying at times, but maybe that's just me. The acting is quite good, and it definitely gets the message across however. Worth a watch!
I haven't seen a movie with more spoiled characters, it's almost like a mediocre version of the Handmaiden movie, which at least had an edge to it! Don't waste your time.

This film was the most wonderful piece of art I have ever had the pleasure of viewing. It was perfection.The emotion is so raw and tangible, it is as if you could reach through the screen and grab it. I was entirely captivated for the whole film and I have never felt so connected to a film in such a natural and real way that doesn't feel manufactured. The cast, director, writers... everyone who took part in this film did a phenomenal job. Emotions and raw love and sensuality and sexual tension are so strong and powerful and conveyed in such a playful, humorous, delicate way that it took my breath away.There is nothing I can say about this film other than the fact that everyone should watch this. Absolutely everyone. You will never see anything like this again.
Such a beautiful well written film with many messages. Must watch again.

This film is a masterpiece. The acting and direction are magnificent. Timothee Chalamet should have won the Oscar. Armie Hammer and Michael Stuhlbarg should both have been nominated. Stuhlbarg's final scene with Chalamet is beautiful, heartbreaking, perfection. The final shot of Chalamet during the end credits is devastating The emotion playing on his face while life continues on behind him.is haunting. On a final note, read the book this film is based on.

There are many very wonderful scenes in this film, but none quite so moving as Timothee Charlomet in the closing credits. Timothee's performance throughout was just so natural and convincing that I'm tempted to say it was flawless (he should have received the Oscar!). I loved him, and can't wait to see him in The King. I thought Aimee Hammer two rungs below Timothee - somewhat less convincing (in my humble opinion). Just not so natural in the role (maybe intentionally, and he's certainly cute). Michael Stuhlbarg's advice to his son near the end was one of the more surprising aspects of the film - didactic in form, and all the more welcome for that (after all, some good solid instruction in tolerance never goes amiss among our species). What a lucky boy to have such a generous, sensible, plainly loving father! Finally, Michael's smiles, facial expressions and intonations reminded me so much of the great Robin Williams (they could so easily be brothers!) and added even more to the pleasure of the film).

Call Me By Your Name was a beautiful, well-acted and well-directed film. However it is a tad overrated for the following reasons:1. WHERE IS THE CONFLICT????? The two main characters (I think they might both be bisexual), discover throughout the course of the movie that they have a romantic connection. Then one of them leaves. Then the other cries about it. Then his dad says he knew about their relationship and is ok with it. There was no conflict, save the girlfriend breaking up with Elio because he didn't see her for three days. Why is that a reason for breaking up, and why is that the most conflict the movie has? Although, I will say that Elio is very scared to come on to Oliver, and that's part of his character arc. But that's not enough to warrant my interest in the story.2. A couple of shots that were too disgusting. Why were they there? That was silly.3. Nothing much happens in the movie. Many scenes have no effect on the plot. Sadly, I will probably never watch this film again. That this got a Best Picture Nomination over I, Tonya and Blade Runner 2049 is beyond me. Mostly completely BORING Oscar Bait. However, the cinematography and acting is superb. 7/10.

I'm a 48 y.o. heterosexual female (though none of that matters), and "Call Me By Your Name" is my favorite movie ever (and I'm a movie fanatic). Timothee Chalamet playing Elio is my favorite character. Namaste.
Love is not specified for man and woman, love is for all

This movie did not convince me. The way that these guys get envolved may feel erotic to some, but the director chose to rush this process too much to make this love look real. 
Timothée Chalamet is charming and plays his role with a brave palette of young enthusiasm. But Armie Hammer is not convincing as a summer love. For some reason it feels like he is not right for the part. His play is too cold and he lacks a rough edge. On top of that, he seems too old to play this role. 
The father's scene near the end of the movie made impression on me but the scenes that follow are too cliche to rate this movie high. All in all a good attempt, but certainly not the erotic movie that some reviewers make you want to believe.

reviews.review_title: Lotta False Notes But GREAT Scenery
reviews.content: "Movie I think you'd like", my son texted me. "'Call Me By Your Name.' Kind of like an Italian 'Brideshead.' Clueless rich people in gorgeous Northern Italy."And "Call Me By Your Name" _is_ kind of like "Brideshead." If "Brideshead" had been directed by, say, Eric Rohmer.I didn't _dislike_ it.I thought it was pretty Nicholas Spark-y, actually. _Sentimental_. The avante garde-ness derives from the fact that it portrays a gay relationship.The two leads struck me as having very little chemistry, but then I'm not a gay male myself, so what do I know? In particular, the impossibly Anglo-handsome Armie Hammer - who, I take it, is related to the baking soda - is a really terrible actor.The Dionysian-curled but weak-chinned Timothee Chalamet is a _better_ actor. We know this because he was in every single movie made last year! (Chalamet also just effectively ended Woody Allen's directing career by making a public announcement yesterday. (Woody Allen hasn't made a good movie for at least a decade, so regardless of how you come down on the Dylan Molestation Issue, this is no great loss.)Towards the end of "Call Me By Your Name", there's a completely hilarious scene - though it wasn't actually played for laughs - in which Timothee Chalamet's distinguished archeologist father tells Timothee that the relationship he had with the baking soda heir was a - smirk, smirk! - "_special_ friendship", and that he - _Dad_ - had also had a "_special_ friendship," but that alas! it had not been allowed to flower, presumably because of repressive attitudes toward sex in the 1960s.I'm sorry, but attitudes toward sex were _so_ much _less_ repressive in the 1960s than they were in the 1980s when "Call Me By Your Name" is supposed to take place.Also, what teenager - gay or straight - really wants to hear old Dad blithering about his sex life?Teenagers _hate_ any intimation of the fact that their parents may be sexual creatures!I mean, they may concede that their parents had to do it _once_ in order to conceive _them_, but they're sure their parents did not enjoy it. And they definitely _don't_ want to hear about it.So, lots and lots of false notes in this movie!On the other hand, _great_ status detail! Tortelli cremaschi! Apricot trees. When the credits started rolling, I immediately began browsing tours to Lombardy.

reviews.review_title: Mystery of love? More like mystery of why this has 8/10
reviews.content:
Why does everybody love this movie? This movie wasted two hours of my life and though I usually waste whole days of my life this has ANGERED ME BEYOND LIMITS. Firstly, the positives. It looks pretty and I like the last song. Now on to EVERYTHING I HATED.
What the hell was that transition song? We would watch a whole 2 minute clip of them cycling away with no music but as soon as elio was walking from one point to the other they would play the song for like two seconds. It doesn't fit at all! It wouldn't fit in any movie it's so strange.What confused me most was when Elio was admitting he liked Armies character (don't even remember his name? Oliver?). It came out of nowhere and I didn't even know what was happening. Then they started being romantic and it was like WHAT???? Elio was trying to AVOID armie but then suddenly loves him? And the age difference is whack.Why didn't this movie come with subtitles? Half the people speak multiple languages and I couldn't even tell if I was listening to French, Italian or German by the end. Obviously I don't want subtitles throughout the whole film, but I had to keep clicking them on and off just to understand the plot. It's not that hard to have them come with the film. It's like mr beans holiday, WHY DOESNT THAT HAVE AUTOMATIC SUBTITLES???The peach scene... Yes its iconic but what the hell. Elio stars crying for no reason? He acts like he has a childhood history of being abused and that's why he cries when fighting Armie. WHO UNDERSTANDS THIS???And the ending with the Dad... When he said "I wish I had done that when I was younger" or something similar, Elio replies with "does mum know?" I thought that Dad was coming out as gay, but apparently not.A movie should only be two hours if it needs two hours and this easily could be a twenty minute short film.
