Well, thank you for giving a chance to this story and making it a remarkable lovestory movie.I have watched some movies and series of two men love and also many storyloves with straight characters but actually most of them are forgotten. I think of "Call Me by Your Name" everytime somebody asks me about a good romantic movie.I hope you release the second part in an early time because I missed it so bad and I want to know the rest of their love story.Wish good luck and more successes for you.

reviews.review_title: A Truly Breathtaking Piece Of Cinema
reviews.content:
Set during a summer in 1980's Northern Italy. Elio Perlman (Timothee Chalamet) a 17-year-old who spends his days in his family's 17th century villa transcribing music, reading and flirting with his friend Marzia (Esther Garrel). One day, Oliver (Armie Hammer), a 24-year-old American college graduate student. Arrives as the annual summer intern tasked with helping Elio's father (Michael Stuhlbarg). Although initially irritated by Oliver's presence. Elio soon forms a connection with Oliver and they both soon discover the heady beauty of awakening that will change their lives forever.
First of all James Ivory's script is spectacular. It's wonderfully adapted from Andre Aciman's novel and really captures the sensual feeling and setting of the story. From the opening credits I was simply transfixed and it hooked me in to the story instantly. I immediately became interested and wanted to learn more about the characters and setting which is due to the excellent script.
Timothee Chalamet is incredible. This is his breakout performance and his first major lead role in a film and he does not disappoint. You can almost tell what he is thinking just from his facial expressions, he doesn't even have to open his mouth and he conveys so much emotion. His character in the story is discovering things about himself and trying to come to terms with these things. He gives such an emotionally resonant performance and it grew on me throughout the film. 
Armie Hammer Portrays Oliver. Its a great performance. He is so entertaining to watch because of his mannerisms, and the quotable lines he delivers throughout the film which made me laugh out loud in some scenes. He again also conveys a lot of emotion without even opening his mouth. His character is also trying to come to terms with things which makes his character vulnerable in some parts of the film. The chemistry between Armie Hammer and Timothee Chalamet is also mesmerising to watch on screen.
The rest of the supporting cast were equally amazing. Michael Stuhlbarg portrays Elio's Father. Who is absolutely phenomenal in this film. He is a very open Father to Elio and he is also very intelligent. Towards the end of the film he gives a powerful monologue about acceptance to Elio which almost brought me to tears. Unfortunately his performance will be sadly overlooked due to the main two actors. Also Elio's Mother Annella (Amira Caser) and his friend Marzia (Esher Garrel) were also great additions to the supporting cast.
With this film being a smaller independent production it's hard to know what to expect from the production design. Thankfully it's excellent. The 17th century villa and the sculptures all around the house are glorious to look at. There's a timeless quality to this story and to the film overall which is marvellous. That is a very rare feat for any film to achieve. 
The music in this film is truly incredible. Sufjan Stevens wrote two original songs for this film. Mystery Of Love and Visions Of Gideon. He also included his previously written song Futile Devices but with a (Doveman Remix) this time. As all three songs played over the film I got goosebumps because of the affect and emotion it added to the film, it was extraordinary. The lyrics for each song are wonderful and perfectly fit the theme and purpose of the story. Also the already produced music used in the film was perfectly selected by music supervisor Robin Urdang. 
Luca Guadagnino's direction is truly splendid. The way in which he captured the source material and the sensual setting of the environment is fantastic. There is a scene in particular where the camera slowly follows the main two characters moving around a statue and it was just breathtaking to look at. This film is truly a work of art and is a shining example of filmmaking at it's absolute finest. I have decided it's his best film yet although he hasn't directed much, this should hopefully get him much more exposure as a director.
Call Me By Your Name is truly a breathtaking piece of cinema. The performances from all the actors especially the main two are outstanding. The music is beautiful and heartbreaking. The chemistry between Armie Hammer and Timothee Chalamet is fantastic. The films message of acceptance is so powerful and relevant to our time. Every single frame of this film has stuck with me ever since the credits rolled and I will never forget it.

I didn't watch the movie as a tribute to the LGBT movement or anything related. In fact, I knew very little about it, only that the trailer seemed nice. So I was sincerely amazed by the depth of the experience I had. I could sense the hot Italian summer, I could feel the teen spirit of the pre-digital age, when everything was new and fresh. I could have been one of the girls on those village outdoor discos, where everything is public and yet, everything is personal and intimate. There are no witnesses in the humid summer nights, but the Moon and the stars. 
I was immersed in that summer, I could feel what the actors were feeling, their passions and questions and hopes. It could have been my first love or anybody else's! 
I'm a little sad that this movie will go under the umbrella of some LGBT Lolilta, when it is so much more. The story is beautiful and real and if people could leave aside their prejudices, I'm sure everybody would relate to it. At least anybody pre-digital. Life was charming back then. When there were still forbidden fruits and first times.

One of THE. BEST. MOVIES. I've ever seen in my life. Chalamet is indeed, a revelation. A gift. So uninhibited. He projects every expression imaginable through his eyes. Effortlessly. His acting is stunning. So real, you feel it ISN'T acting. For me, two of the most fantastically real, heartbreaking, moments from Chalamet were, when he sobbed in Hammer's arms before telling him, I don't want you to go, and when he called his mother to come get him from the station. He makes your heart ache. Armie Hammer is one of the most beautiful men on this planet. He and Chalamet SHINE. Armie was a surprise for me because of the ease with which he fell into this role. Beautiful. Sensual. Have I said, beautiful? This film makes you FEEL. Michael Stuhlbarg's speech to a gutwrenchingly heartbroken Elio was icing on the proverbial cake. People were audibly sobbing in the theater at the end. I was one of them. I can't say enough about this movie. I've seen it twice. Will see it again. Am almost through the audio book (Hammer narrates. Omg... my heart... ) and I will buy the DVD. I know Guadagnino has mentioned a possible sequel. Please, God, let it be so. Standing O. A thousand times over.

This film is the most delicate narrative of intimacy I've already seen. It evokes the feeling of what was, what is and what could have been in a love so pure and intense as a summer in northern Italy. Absolutely sublime!

Somewhat strange I did not find something interesting except landscapes ... When watching the movie you see the life of a teenager turbulent in a normal daily life and boring, which made pearls deviation, in my view the film is not appropriate and I will not watch it again or advise anyone to watch it.

reviews.review_title: An intersectional triumph!!! A victory for narcissistic hedonism!!!
reviews.content: I know: the filmmakers were adapting a book and couldn't depart from its core. But you and I can have a thought experiment with two alternate plots, can't we? Here goes. Alternate plot #1: In northern Italy in the 1980s, seventeen-year old Elia begins a relationship with Oliver, her art professor father's twenty-four year old cis-gender research assistant for the summer, with whom she bonds over her budding sexuality, their shared Jewish identity, and the charming north Italian landscape. At first Oliver is reluctant to respond to Elia's approaches but, as the age of consent in Italy is fourteen (because Juliet Capulet), he yields, to their mutual satisfaction. After their first sex, when Oliver is away, Elia, overcome with desire for Oliver, satisfies her passion with a zucchini from her family's kitchen garden (a motif borrowed from the "Therèse Philosophe" scene in the 1973 masterpiece Immoral Tales), beautifully illustrating how natural and wholesome their love is. Later, at her progressive sorta-Jewish parents' positive urging, Elia and Oliver travel together to Bergamo, get drunk, have lots of sex, and run around under gushing waterfalls calling each other by their own names, a courageous experiment in transexuality. Six months later, after Oliver has returned to the U. S. and Elia has had an abortion, Elia's mother consoles her tearful daughter with wise words about the summertime sex romp as something "very special."Alternate plot #2: In northern Italy in the 1980s, seventeen-year old Elio feels sexually attracted to Oliver, his art professor father's twenty-four year old bisexual research assistant for the summer, with whom he slowly forms a relationship over his budding sexuality, their shared Jewish identity, and the charming north Italian landscape. At first Oliver is strongly tempted to yield to Elio's advances, but manfully resists, explaining to Elio the reasons why it would be wrong for them to have sex together: their obvious age difference (despite the fact that the age of consent in Italy is fourteen); the betrayal of Elio's parents' trust; the moral confusion that might be caused to a still-developing young man; and the deep emotional damage caused by reducing sex to meaningless and casual hedonistic gratification. They travel together to Bergamo, where Oliver teaches Elio about Greek and Roman sculpture and they form a lasting friendship worthy of the name. Years later they meet in New York, each married with children and happy lives. They look each other square in the eye and share a firm handshake. Elio thanks Oliver for his moral courage and self-control all those years ago.The woke film industry just cannot help itself from nagging and lecturing us about how hip homosexuality is and how most of us are bigoted clodhoppers for not getting their message no matter how often they send it. Well, this message is pretty clear. Did you miss the allusions to the Greek myth of Narcissus, what with all the ponds and swimming pools, not to mention the silly "call my by your name" thing? Elio: "I love you, Elio!!" Oliver: "I love you, Oliver!" In another scene Oliver is reviewing images of classical Greek sculpture with his professor host and all he has to say about the Charioteer of Delphi is "So sensual," as if the viewer's hard-on is the true test of an immortal artwork's beauty. If you value your time on this earth, do not waste two and a half precious hours in the theater enduring this thing.

This film has the potential to cause real harm by normalizing this kind of sexual predation. It could be particularly damaging for LGBT youth, who are already at a high risk for depression and suicide.So no, "Call Me by Your Name" isn't a radical, brilliant piece of art. We need to call it by its name. That name is abuse.The movie is nicely directed and filmed, but the underlying themes are not nice.

reviews.content:

Plot: 17-year-old Elio has a lustful romance (his first) with Oliver (an older grad student) and comes out to his parents. Oliver gets engaged to a woman.

reviews.review_title: A New Era for Cheesy Films.
reviews.content: As society changes, art as a mirror of it has to do the same. This is made clear in one scene of this film: "The cinema is a mirror of reality". And that is a fact, a truth that the seventh art has embraced: Tell the stories that affect this world or those that deserve attention. And today, the day I write this, I can say that we live in an authentic time of transition. Social struggles seek to empower themselves more and more through entertainment media by breaking with traditional taboos. Moonlight, winner of the Oscar for Best Film on 2016, is a proof of that. However, as I said with that project, Call me by Your Name gets a great relevance for this, not necessarily for being a great movie.The script, in my opinion, is shown as the strong pillar of this film. In this case, the internal conflict that the protagonist suffers when experiencing infatuation towards a person of the same sex. The most interesting thing, and that is where I think the mastery of this script rests, is the fact of managing the main conflict of gay love no longer having society or conservatism as the main antagonist (Although a key era is used to deal with with taboo), but to self-established barriers and self-absorption. In particular, this aspect is accentuated when the adolescent repeats on several occasions the phrase: "Is it better to confess, or to die?". Personally, that scene near the end of the film in which Elio talks to his father about the adventure he had with Oliver is the central point. Deep and moving scene. Good dialogue and a soundtrack that perfectly embellishes the story.The development of the characters, however, is not something we can applaud. Except for Elio (emphasizing the work of Timothée Chalamet, even if Gary Oldman proved to be a better contender for the award) and perhaps his father, the other characters lack a real purpose, except Oliver, who still think that only appears in the film to play the conflicting lover ... nothing more. In his character, an attempt was made to insert a bit of resistance to the idea of same-sex romance, but in the end it only occupies a role that, although necessary to tell the story, lacks real depth, unless Elio is next to him. The film in general responds to all the actions of the protagonist: his female lover, his mother, the Armie Hammer's character, the housekeeper. Although Elio is an incredibly complex character and a reflection of many people who live through the changes he goes through, the rest of the cast seems to have no real interference in the plot and in the way it develops.It is evident that Call me by your Name pretends to be seen as part of a new phase of Hollywood work. And, in my opinion, it accomplishes that task. It is another romantic film and to a certain extent honeyed. Like an authentic Chick Flick, it is full of literary references, live music, cheesy phrases and over much longer than history could merit. If we do the mental exercise of extracting the LGBT+ theme, we will notice that it is like any other romantic foreign film, with an interesting plot, extraordinary landscapes and characters that cause tenderness, but without going any further. Therefore, I believe that it is precisely the theme of love between people of the same sex that is so relevant to this production. And, in my opinion, a good film is the one that is capable of introducing this theme at the same time that it tells a story of masterly plot and at least optimal filming quality. While the intention behind Call me by your Name may be considered admirable, I do not think that the same can be said for its filmographic quality.

reviews.review_title: You were more me than I had ever been myself
reviews.content:
Some movies are just magic. This is one of them. It is hard to explain why it can affect people so much, but one can try to list out the reasons one can think of.Because it is created by a group of genius, including the writers (novel and screenplay), director, actors, musician, etc.
Because it is filmed in the beautiful city of Crema, Italy.
Because it depicts desire, one of the fundamental essence of human, so well.
Because it is about love is love is love, regardless of form or gender.
Because.There is really no need to explain to be honest. If you watch it, you would love it.Never has a movie touched me so deeply, in the soul, and left me speechless and lost in thoughts. After the first viewing, I read the book, watched the movie for the second time, listened to the audio book, read/watched countless essays/reviews/interviews about the movie, and now am preparing to read the script as well. I am still constantly in awe of the new details discovered from the book or the movie. The insights from the creators also help adding so many layers to the movie which I am excited to watch many more times.Here are a few things I particularly love, among the overall unique infatuation I have with this piece of art:While there is no doubt that the Perlmans depicted in the book is very warm and loving, the center theme of the book itself is still much focused on Elio and his coming-of-age discovery of himself. On the other hand, the director of the movie, Luca Guadagnino, made certain changes in the movie to better fit his description of the project - "This is a movie about a family, compassion, transmission of knowledge, of being better people because someone's otherness changes you," Guadagnino told The Guardian in 2017. For instance, some scenes originally only involved Elio and/or Oliver in the book, but Luca included the Perlmans parents as well which showed beautiful exchanges between the generations.The movie is also all about intimacy, distance, and the chase and catch game between characters. It has the perfect depiction of a passionate relationship between two people from the beginning, and sadly to the end. Testing water in the beginning and wondering if the other person is indeed interested or everything is just a fantasy and projection of your own affections. One moment you are so close to each other, then separation can come disruptively just seconds later. The abrupt 'later' is a perfect example. We watch Elio and Oliver's friendship blossoms, and there are so many beautiful moments which just leave us more heartbroken than ever at the end (spoiler alert).Let's also talk about the perfect casting. It is hard to believe that Luca found the perfect Elio and Oliver without any audition or reading. Armie Hammer had a more elaborated profile but no character was as emotionally demanding and vulnerable as Oliver. Timothée Chalamet was relatively new as a young star. Who would have known he could make Elio so alive and complex? Don't even get me started on the scenes where they demonstrated master class of acting, I can make a list. Just one example for each: the last night they spent together for Oliver, and the last scene with credits rolling for Elio. It is truly because of their generosity in sharing their heart and soul as the characters, the movie can be so heart touching and successful.It is so obvious how much Elio and Oliver were in love even though they never said "I love you", not even once. The closest we got is the ambiguous "I love this", spoken by Elio to Oliver on Monet's berm. I am definitely not exaggerating when I say this is one of the most poetic movies I have ever watched.I can only say this is truly a masterpiece and timeless and will be admired by generations. My deepest gratitude to André Aciman for the beautiful words he created, to Luca Guadagnino for his brilliant illustration on screen, and to all the actors for their authentic performances. This is going to be my favourite movie for years (or forever).

reviews.review_title: Best Coming of Age Story in The History of Motion Picture!
reviews.content: I won't give spoilers, but I will say that Elio and Oliver's relationship very closely resembles the first same sex experience I had as a boy. The plot line is solid, the actors really become their characters - and while not sexual, the close frienship has followed them into real life. If you haven't seen it, I highly encourage you to watch the trailer and go see it.

Not read the book, not gay (but equally not homophobic), just wanting to see a good movie; those were my starting conditions as I saw this movie.First, the technical part. I could not disagree more on many people calling this movie "beautiful".I mean the camera work is not awful, but showcasing a foot in water for about 10 seconds (with no reason whatsoever behind it), just to name one example, is not sth. I would call "good camera work". Furthermore the picture looks a little desaturated and grainy at times.But the full extend of that low budget 4 Mio Euros movie is what you get to hear. That is, if you even hear anything except for that annoying bird twittering.Seriously, I watched this movie in Dolby Surround and the Mixing was the worst, I have ever heard in a movie. It was so bad actually, the entire thing sounded like a cheap TV-Production, as the recorded micro-sound always came from the center-speaker. They did not even dare trying to split voices or other Sounds recorded on set onto other channels. The only thing you get to hear from those other channels is that stupid annoying twittering (and sometimes the even more unfitting Music.)
It had nothing to do with the Plot, which I will come to later on.The only good thing, that I think this movie has, is its performances. Mr. Chamalet performed excellently and also Mrs Garrel and Mr. Stuhlbarg did their job well. But even those were not able to show emotions or anything of interest until the very end of that movie.Mr. Hammer tried really hard, but eventually I did not believe him completely.The Plot: /
Thats right, this movie has none. At least none worth mentioning. But for those of you who need it, have it: (I will not call them by their names, that is stupid)
The one like mid 30s guy, I will call him "A" comes to Italian town where 17 year-old guy "B" lives with his family. They both like each other, but cannot tell anyone, not even themselves. They both have a beautiful girl lying around (that just so happens to happen in Italy, even if you are really, I mean really weird, come to that later), which puts B in the situation of having to choose. He finally chooses in favor of A over the girl, which is not big of a deal for her (she loves him and is fine with staying friends with him - jup that is part of the movie). A has to go away again, which makes B sad. His father tells him sth. About how special the relationship of the two is (somehow everybody knows about them) and B cries in front of a fire.END OF THE MOVIE.That is all that happens in OVER TWO HOURS! I can make up a story myself in that time that has more complexity to it.Well there are some weird non-fitting put-ins that I left out like the other gay couple that just flys by for a few seconds or that weird hiking scene, but lets just forget about those for a second.WAIT!Almost forgot about the not-ending sex scenes of B sleeping with the girl, himself and A. Those are very unpleasant to watch and make up half of the movie. And no, I do not prefer to watch heterosexual people having sex at all, I just find it very unpleasant to watch two other people having sex in general, no matter the sexuality. Furthermore, there are enough scenes of them doing weird stuff, like sniffing at another ones worn underpants. I mean What The Hell? Who does that?So... What is the hidden meaning of this "movie"?THERE IS NONE! This movie tells a boring, way too far stretched story that has no meaning whatsoever other than the one that - at least in my opinion - is omnipresent in modern day culture and nothing new or exciting to be discussed. The technical aspects of this film are underwhelming and the only thing preventing me from giving this one a 1/10 is the good acting by some of the actors (seemingly the only thing that those 4 Mio Euros have been used for).Seriously, why the praise?

My English is not strong enough to describe this film. I put it simple, this is what i call the real art, when the plot transcend the screen and comes to life. Call me by your name is made out to be an amazing romantic/coming of age film. And while the film does deliver, it is in neither of those areas. The lead actors have little to no chemistry, and it is unclear they even have an attraction until it is explicitly stated by the characters. One could argue that the relatively large age gap between the two is responsible for and lack of chemistry, however several films have pulled off much more compelling stories with an even more significant difference in age. The film and actors attempt to create an unspoken, slow burn attraction between the two characters-which is always compelling- but fails to do so successfully. As a result, the minimal dialogue and other lack of interaction between Oliver and Elio becomes less a way to draw the audience into their romance and more a confusing choice that makes their relationship seem like an afterthought instead of the focal point of the story. With that being said, the film is beautifully shot, and does an amazing job of setting the scene of a 1983 Italian villa. The story of Elio on it's own is compelling, however mostly due to the supporting characters and the way the film portrays subtleties of being 17 and free for a summer. The father's monologue is written and delivered beautifully, and communicates a message so good it makes you wish it had been present in the film the whole time.

Truly masterful art work as seen here is very rare in film nowadays. Despite my great excitement as I settled down to watch this, I didn't anticipate how much a film, this film, could affect me, and wasn't prepared for the emotional awakening upon the first and repeat viewings. It may be a cliche to say a film can change your life, yet Call Me By Your Name effortlessly and effectively twinges at your nostalgia through exhibiting a freedom in the perfect idyllic setting to explore yourself as a human being. It introduces you to the Northern Italian home of Greek professor Sam Perlman and his wife and teenage son, who welcome in a student every summer to assist him. This year the confident American Oliver has come to stay, his arrival opening the film and the door to this tranquil oasis where he blunders in with his natural charm and vigour, completely entrancing the Perlman's 17 year old son Elio. What develops between them over the summer is a pure and unfiltered romance, with time as their only enemy. It's hard to tell which performance shines brightest here. The whole ensemble of the cast is perfectly orchestrated, with characters presented so vibrantly and free that they fully capture the scene, almost as if you are watching real life unfold before you. Michael Stuhlbarg and Amira Casar are so effortless as the relaxed intellectual parents with a rich and eclectic social circle, though it is in Mr Perlman's final speech to his heartbroken son that truly captures the films sorrowful joy and it's ode to first stomach-wrenching heart-racing knee-quaking love and the bottomless despair when it ends. Yet the real beauty of this film comes in Elio's growing reluctant infatuation for the older man and the passion that blossoms when his attraction is reciprocated. It is impossible to untangle the performances of Armie Hammer and Timothée Chalamet as Oliver and Elio respectively. Oliver's greatest moments lie in the quiet removal of his barriers as he and Elio grow closer, the freedom he exhibits, both in his experience of the summer and his romance with Elio, and also in his quieter despair when the reality of time catches up to them. Armie captures Oliver's freedom masking a deeper longing, so eloquently and naturally, and you feel his inhibitions lower with Oliver's as he gives himself so openly and honestly to the role. Timothée Chalamet, meanwhile, delivers such a masterful and mature performance that it is hard to believe that Elio is not a real person whose life you are capturing a glimpse of. So very infrequently can an actor capture the inner turmoil going on in his characters thoughts, but Timmy breathes Elio's thoughts and desires; he wears them on his skin so exposed and unfiltered with his emotions, and whilst the end of the film should be celebrated from such a young and up and coming performer, it is in his earlier scenes of his growing intense irritation by and infatuation of Oliver that I enjoyed the most, from his fidgety restlessness, to his lingering gazes, to his embarrassment and insecurity around the more self assured Oliver, to most especially the disappointed, jealous thoughtful glare at Oliver on the dance floor as he realises the depth of his desire for the first time.
 
The nostalgia the film conjures up within you is life-defining; Call Me By Your Name transports you to a time and a place where life was unfiltered; whether for the characters in the film or the cast and crew who made the film, it captures a moment, a memory; a kiss you will never have again; a touch you will never feel again; an experience that comes and goes with a blink of the eye, but leaves you irreversibly transformed. As a viewer, the film lingers within you, like first loves, past romances and unrequited attractions, bringing you much anguish and hope in equal measure that, like Mr Perlman softly advises, you should embrace and rejoice in rather than kill the pain of the heartbreak. Call Me By Your Name is timeless; it is proof that masterpieces of art don't just appear on canvas or carved it stone; they can be in an actor's gaze, an actor's expressions, the raw relenting submission to a character's mind frame, and to the idyllic experience of the perfect summer with the perfect person.

reviews.review_title: A movie that lingers on in the mind for days
reviews.content:
Rarely does seeing a movie affect me as much as Call Me By Your Name did. The perfect portrayal of longing resonated with me for two or three days after watching it. There is something about the way this movie depicts the longing of a first love, gently getting closer and closer to someone in timid, mutual exploration... the Summer days and evenings listening to a portable radio in a small Italian village with your thoughts constantly wrapped up in desire and doubt. Small details of this film just made me smile (the Invicta backpack, the old woman "cleaning" green vegetables outside in the Sun, the old men at the bar...). Oliver/Armie Hammer's admiration of ancient Greek statues parallels the ephebic, classical beauty of Elio/Timothee Chalamet. It just made me cry when Elio notices Oliver was wearing the same shirt as the first day he got there, and asks if he can keep it when Oliver leaves. There are some striking similarities with Eric Rohmer's "Conte d'été", in some scenes the influence of this movie seems especially obvious... like a tribute from a way to interpret love, to another way to interpret love.
It's such a deep, sensitive story on the delicate, but ultimately cruel nature of longing...

From the calls of the European swifts announcing the Italian village scenes to the almost painful-to-watch descent into hopeless lust of Elio (Chalamet, radiant), we get to be passengers in this juggernaut of gorgeousness. One moment is held up by many a review which I have trouble agreeing with - the monologue of Elio's father (Stuhlbarg). Rather stilted and slight false tone. Other than that, a masterpiece.

We could be talking about just one more love story, except for the fact that what Elio and Oliver had gone much deeper than we are used to having in a relationship. 
Luca Guadagnino takes us to this perfect summer dream where every color seems to be intensified by a brilliant sunshine, in a warm weather that almost dismiss wearing clothes. It is the kind of scenery that everyone could picture a beautiful -first love story. 
However, what makes this romance special is that it comes from a emotion of fear. But where is there fear, there is also a desire, and breaking through it together it is like making a pact.
A lovely celebration of sensory pleasure has started since then, be it in the form of food, flesh or music. They surrendered themselves to the best what a moment can bring, just by being present and feeling.
There was something so natural in how this relationship unfolded that it seems as if remaining in secret front others judgment allowed them to be whoever they want. Is like having finding freedom in a prison. The couple is lost in a space of enjoyment and we are also together, being driven by wide shots to close ups of pleasure. 
Call me by your name is labelled by many as gay film, which confirms how people's mindsets are still boxed. Nobody seems to care that much, or feel shocked, about a totally naked woman. It's the men. Anyway, what it´s up to us, the audience, to enjoy our sense of voyeurism rather stare at other people's gender.

This movie is everything. the passion and tenderness that chalamet and hammer bring to the screen is memorable and beautiful. i'm now looking forward to the sequel(s) to see these characters together once again. i haven't felt so moved by a movie since before sunrise, and i only hope guadagnino can do what linklater did for that series. i really believe he's created something exceptional.

reviews.review_title: A Love Letter To First And Young Love
reviews.content: Grab a match and light a taper candle... then watch it burn.Slow burn romance done right come far and few between. Call Me By Your Name is a force of nature film that in my opinion can be labeled the most triumphant of its category. 'A masterpiece' would be an obvious choice of words if it didn't feel so much like an insult to the brilliance and beauty of this movie.Deemed distasteful and inappropriate by some, CMBYN is center for controversy and dismay. Touching on subjects of same sex love and relations and more so disliked the age gap between the lead characters Elio and Oliver.With what I found, the age gap is definitely inappropriate - much like thousands of first loves are. Which is why it translated to me as brutally honest and heartbreaking.The rawness and realness of Elio and Olivers relationship as it slowly pans out leaves us sad and hopeful for Elio. We root for him as he tackles his own identity and feelings and want to see him come out on the other side triumphant. Though we learn that things don't go his way similar yet again to most first loves.The film tells a painfully relatable story through beautiful locations and shots, colorful music and words and brilliant acting.It's impossible for me to watch this movie without feeling like I too am somewhere in northern Italy and for that I think the makers created a success.
I watched this movie few days ago. i didn't expect a happy ending but after when i finished i felt like i was breaking into tears..since then i am not okay. this movie is a masterpiece...

Another is the script is abstract and thought-provoking. the camera angle at the Palvie( or sth) circular war monument when two guys talk is good at digging into a analysing character's feelings. Finally, the Elio eyes are tearful, which makes me remember the film well after it ends.I would recommend this for those who have sensitive souls and those who have an open-minded view.

reviews.review_title: Must be seen for what it is.
reviews.content: This movie is mind candy. As others have pointed out, the characters are poorly-developed cutouts, and the only powerful scene is the father-son conversation. And I cannot help thinking that might be received like water in a desert. I watched it on Prime, the subtitles, I think original, and unextinguishable, are, to an Italian speaker like me, a distraction bordering on meaningless.But I loved it. So there. I am a straight guy, so have no affinity for what some suppose to be the pornographic aspects of the film, but isolating one protagonist as a character seems to me to make it very personal, as if seen through his eyes. The sex scenes came across to me as reasonable, awkwardness in coming-of-age sex is completely realistic.It is nicely shot, both the cinematography and soundtrack are complimentary rather than obtrusive.If a gritty romance set in the streets of Chicago or London is what you are looking for, you will be horribly disappointed, but if you are fed up with reading Camus or McEwan, and fancy a pocket romance, it may be for you. At my age (61) I find meaningful classics less poignant than once I might, and sometimes just want to get away from it all.

If this story were placed in a vacuum, it wouldn't interest me, but it makes you feel a certain way and transports you to a place that is quite enjoyable.

Are you tired of trivial primitive love stories? Cant you handle another cheap gay love story based of discrimination? Are you curious when will something replace the weekend as the "last popular gay movie"? Look no more. Call me by your name has it all. Sophisticated modern image of love. Cliche free plot. Reasonable depth. Acting that suprises and does not offend. Additionally, it even makes justice to the book. Increadible experience to the last scene.

To those giving this film a negative nod, maybe you just don't relate enough and are just pure narrow minded. The movie depicts every (or some) closeted gay man's story. No matter what you say about the sex scenes, it happens in real life. It is true. It's just right that Timothée got nominated for an Oscar because he did justice to his character. Even without saying a word, his eyes said it all. Although some of the reviewers here are inputting religious stuff in all this, we cannot deny the fact that the story is not far from happening in real life. Again. It happens. And don't get me started with the peach scene. Don't be a hypocrite and say you haven't done or even thought of doing something like it. The movie took 2 hours to finish, but every emotion needed to be felt. And for me, it was beautifully done. I just can't wait for the next installment.

The setting is enchanting. The cinematography is engaging. The golden light of an Italian summer is almost intoxicating. I would love to see another version of this where the actors are digitally extricated from the movie so I could have enjoyed it more. There also could have been more fresh fruit. I don't really care for apricots.

reviews.review_title: Disgusted by all of the awful, tasteless 1 star reviews.
reviews.content: "Call Me by Your Name" is a difficult movie to watch and think it's worth a one star. All of the bad reviews are screaming pedophilia and jail time. The age of consent in Italy is 14 years old, I wish people would do their research before spilling their incorrect opinions. "Call Me by Your Name" is a sensual, erotic, yet innocent story. It is about so much more than a gay boy finding himself. By the end of the movie I will guarantee you'll feel every emotion coursing through your body, whether it be resentment or sadness. You'll be attached to the characters.

reviews.review_title: The most relateable movies in a very long time!
reviews.content:
Call Me by Your Name is a movie about love, lust and all the feelings circulating when you are in love for the first time. 
17 year old Elio is vacationing in Northern Italy with his academic parents when Oliver, a 24 year old grad student arrives, destined to be the fathers assistent. Elio is instantly fascinated by the older man, and soon after Oliver is also interested in him. 
Even though the movie is about two men falling in love, it is not nescercarily a "gay movie" it is a movie about love, and how love can be between anyone, no matter age, gender or sexuality. 
Call me by your name is the most relateable movie in a long time, for anyone who has ever been in love!

Call me by your name is an incredible movie! If you let yourself go and take the time to watch this movie you'll be pleased! First of all Timothée Chalamet is amazing in this movie. He has no barrier and you can feel every emotion from the character just by his body language and face expressions. Also the chemistry that Armie Hammer and Timothée Chalamet have has Oliver and Elio is incredible. Sometimes I feel like they've been dating for months and asked to do a movie together! Secondly the work of Luca Guadagnino and James Ivory makes the film a masterpiece. The story itself isn't the thing but the way it's told is. After watching it for the first time, I wanted to have what they had. I wanted to go to Crema in Italy and have a summer romance just like they did. It also made me look back to my first love and I think that's wonderful! Call me by your name is about interpretation because it's not labeled. In fact in no way we know Elio's sexual orientation. He was a girlfriend and he is also in love with Oliver but the movie doesn't tell you if he's gay or bisexual or bi-curious or pansexual. It doesn't force you to see the movie a certain way. It's a slow movie so if you prefer action movie it may not be your fav. Some people talked about the age gap between Elio and Oliver. The thing is: the consent age in Italy is 16. Also the parents approves their relationship. Elio is the one who is trying to "convince" Oliver to love him. To conclude the space and time will make you fall in love with the movie. It's this hot italian summer in the 80s where everybody is in swimsuit and plays volleyball. The greek statues and the nature embellish the film. The unbelievable colours and camera angles are boom. GO SEE THIS MOVIE PLEASE!!!!

reviews.review_title: A Celebration of Sexual Predication and Anti-Semitism
reviews.content: This disgraceful film is beautifully filmed and acted. That makes it all the worse as it celebrates an older grad student sexually preying on a 17 year old boy and depicts a Jewish family in the ugliest light possible. Absolutely despicable!

reviews.review_title: Starts off slow... then pulls the viewer into a whirlwind of emotion
reviews.content: Overall, this was a very beautiful movie. That being said, I did enjoy the second hour, after Elio and Oliver started their relationship, much more than the first half. The chemistry between the characters was lovely. I felt the closeness between Elio and his parents, and what a safe, warm life he lived on the villa. I also felt the passion between Elio and Oliver, when they kissed and even when Oliver sat rubbing Elio's feet on the kitchen floor. Call Me By Your Name is a movie filled with love, and although the end is sad, as Elio's father tells him, Elio is better off having experienced such a relationship as the one he shared with Oliver.
I was not emotionally ready for this movie. The script, Timothée and the scenery was absolutely amazing.

reviews.review_title: A slow, cautious beginning, which leads to a monumental ending.
reviews.content: The beginning and the middle of the movie, "Call Me by Your Name", seemed slow, and as if the movie had no purpose except for two guys falling in love -- which we have seen before in plenty of independent films; however, the ending made the movie come together in a monumental way. In particular, the ending was made up of some of the most profound dialogues -- for example, the dialogue between the main character and his father -- I've seen on film, which would not have made sense without the slow, realised progression of the main characters' love. Similarly, the main character wasn't very expressive of his inner emotions throughout the beginning and the middle of the film; however, the very last scene showed the acting chops of Timothée Chalamet - he, without any words, only in his eyes, reflected on the events of the entire film, which gave the audience an opportunity to connect the cautious beginning and middle of the movie to this profound ending. Masterful.

This film is exceptional. Luca Guadagnino creates a beautiful, nostalgic, dreamlike setting. The New York Times called it a "ravishment of the senses," which is so well said - the lighting, the sounds of the house, smells you might imagine, hot summer air- every sensory element creates a backdrop you feel as if you have experienced. The development of the relationship between Elio and Oliver is captured beautifully and recreates moments we've all experienced, fostering a familiarity that makes this not a gay love story, but a classic love story.In the final scene of the film, the audience will feel the intense melancholy Elio is experiencing, while life continues around him. We are reminded in his fathers monologue that this type of sadness can only exist after feeling unimaginable happiness - "Right now there is sorrow and pain, don't kill it, and with it the joy you've felt." Heartbreak is incredibly painful but is also a beautiful reminder of the love we experienced - it is something that deserves to be felt and not repressed, much like this movie, which very much deserves to be felt rather than watched.

This movie just broke me into thousand pieces, put me back together and broke me right again. Amazing, memorable and beautiful in every single aspect.
Everything was on point, from the music to the characters."How you live your life is your business, just remember, our hearts and our bodies are given to us only once. And before you know it, your heart is worn out, and, as for your body, there comes a point when no one looks at it, much less wants to come near it. Right now, there's sorrow, pain. Don't kill it and with it the joy you've felt."

Call Me by Your Name is one of the most visually appealing films I have ever seen. Despite the controversy surrounding the relationship between Elio and Oliver, I could watch this over and over due to the sheer beauty of it. Luca Guadagnino is such an incredible director that has brought Andre Aciman's novel to life so beautifully and sensually and I admire him for that. The way he brings so much emotion into scenes is fantastic, and Timothee Chalamet and Armie Hammer show so much passion and understanding for their characters, playing the roles of Elio and Oliver incredibly. The soundtrack brings so much to the film, Sufjan Stevens absolutely elevated the emotion in Call Me by Your Name to a new level with his music. I would say that if this review was focused only on the cinematography then I would have to give it a 10 as it is simply one of the most visually beautiful films I have ever seen. However, the story lets us down just slightly.The story of Call Me by Your Name is good, even very good. It's not bad, not even average- but it's not great. I think the main issue people find with this film is Elio and Oliver's age gap. And while people try and make excuses such as Elio being over the age of consent in Italy, this doesn't change the 7 year age and maturity gap between the two. Elio was 17, still American high school age, while Oliver was 24, a grown adult man, who was simply more mature than Elio in almost every way. It's debatable on whether this is as big of an issue as some people say it is, but I'm not going to get into that. Other than that, there aren't many outright issues with the story. Some people believe that there are plot holes, but the film is really being portrayed as a collection of Elio's memories, and so they are going to be slightly unreliable and such.Call Me by Your Name is romantic, it's sensual, it's passionate and it's moving, but overall, it's beautiful. Everyone should watch this.
Usually i dont like romantic movies but this stole my heart!

A story so pure, a movie full of human emotions, a summer we have all experienced in our lives more or less. Luca, Armie, Timothée and the rest of the people involved in this movie, from the actors to the people behind the cameras, have created a masterpiece. It is so unique that while watching the movie and experiencing the story of these people you get to feel the summer sun, the taste of the apricot juice, the flow of the water, the night breeze, the emotions of the characters, and with such beautiful music encapsulating all the experience it certainly couldn't be nothing but a movie that everyone should experience

I would like to ask for a second movie with Oliver and Elio . This movie must continue ! It fascinated me , traveled me in places and influenced me positively. I hope this message will reach the man that filmed this masterpiece . 
Kind regards

i can't describe the vibe of the movie..
excellent!

Of for you mathematically challenged, 17 is greater the 14, so there is no unlawful act. That being said. I like the movie, both actors were fine, with the younger one being outstanding. reviews.review_title: Takes you back to your first heartbreak in this most touching way
reviews.content: I love this movie. It is beautiful and heart wrenching and authentic in every way. The acting is phenomenal and it draws out an intense emotion from every person watching. Specifically at the end, Elio's emotions transcend off the screen and into the heart of the viewer. It is hard not to get emotional watching just because it so accurately portrays what it's like to love so hard and then have life naturally get in the way. So much love for this movie. Well done by everyone involved.

reviews.review_title: Perfection - if you read the book
reviews.content:
I loved this movie from beginning to end and if it was up to me, I would have given it the Best Picture Oscar. It was a beautiful adaptation of the book, which I've gone through more times than I care to admit. Some people here say it's slow, boring or lacks depth - that's far from the truth. You have to get that this is Italy in the 80s, it isn't a world of social media, instant content and whatnot. It's "slow" only because it's supposed to be, because it aims to take you on the journey of a serene summer when everything and nothing happen at once. And no way it is boring or shallow if you don't need things to be spelt out for you in explicit words. Understand the meaning of silence too.
However, I do concede that my opinion may be different because I read the novel beforehand. It must have given me an insight into the scenes that those who didn't read the book couldn't grasp. In case you suspect you might not be able to understand what's going on from subtle gestures, I recommend reading it before saying anything about the movie. Just an advice.
Both the film and the book will thankfully linger with me.
The Movie is very very boring I feel like people only like this movie because Timothee Chalamet is in it

Everything in this movie is so beautifully presented. The aesthetic, storyline, acts, they are all so natural and calming. For me, there's only one thing that i'm not a fan of, i can feel the gap between Elio and Oliver, or maybe i should say Timothee and Armie? I feel a little bit of weirdness between these two, but i still LOVE the overall after all. 
I should mention this as well, Timothee Chalamet's acting is so natural and beautiful especially at the ending part where he's squatting in front of the fireplace.
This is a beautiful movie, but perhaps not everyone is able to accept it.

This sensual, beautifully shot film is a delectable delight, just like it's setting and it's location, simply delicious. The cinematography is stunning, and the camera languishes in its beautiful setting, allowing us to watch a beautiful love story develop. It indulges us by taking us on a journey so that we might enjoy the scenery, the long shots and time, above all the time it allows us to linger and watch rather than flitting here and there impatiently as many films do. The beautiful old crumbling house, in a small village in Northern Italy, is wonderful, a character in itself, it is a place of relaxation for the family who spend their summers and Christmas there whilst welcoming friends and family constantly as denotes their generosity of spirit. It is a place of faded grandeur, full of hospitality and love.The acting is superb, and do not believe anyone who says it isn't. The chemistry between the two main characters is electric and so believable and so beautiful to watch, it reminds us all of the intensity of love.For the people who say this film is too long, or boring, I guess they just don't get it. This film is about subtle nuances, the growth of the characters developmentally, their gradual realisation of their feelings for one another. It is a celebration of love in its many forms: of the parents for their son; of Elio and Oliver; of the Perlamans; of Marzia. It reminds me of French and British films which often focus on dialogue and in-depth studies of characters. In this film we are studying human nature and fathoming the decsiions and actions of the protagonists, rather than focusing on dramatic action, loud volume and special effects - those factors which excite some film fans. This film is a triumph for people who enjoy watching people. Loved it and it will remain in my memory for a very long time, probably always. Thank you Luca.

Never before have I watched a movie that I have felt so strongly about that I decided to write a review here. This movie is a complete masterpiece, and the fact that Luca Guadagnino was not nominated for a directing Oscar is just a travesty. This film is as much perfection in filmmaking that is possible: the music, the cinematography, the amazing, seamless flow of all of the performances blended together all create art on the screen. Every second of this film MEANS something, and scenes layer symbolism on top of symbolism.The acting is astoundingly good. From the two leads down to the smallest of supporting characters, the performance quality is first-rate, and all of the characters help build each other into being more complex and sympathetic. Timothee Chalamet is a revelation, and someone that will be garnering more awards nominations in the future. Every move he makes, his tones of voice, every little movement or gesture puts Elio's character on display; intelligent, curious, cautious, uncertain....every emotion he is feeling, as he is feeling it, is on full view. Armie Hammer's performance is stunning. I have been a fan of his for some time now, and never have I seen such an emotionally restrained and subtle performance. Hammer performs Oliver as both cocky and confident, and sensitive and hesitant, all with equal skill. Michael Stulbarg's monologue at the end of the movie is quietly powerful, brilliantly written and performed, and presents the epitome of what parent we all would like to have.The pacing of the film, and the lingering way in which many scenes are shot just accentuate the langour of summer. The soundtrack is a beautiful and emotional backdrop for the film. Is it a "slow" movie? Yes, absolutely, and by design. It allows the viewer to luxuriate in it even more. A movie that has lasted with me in the week since initially seeing it, and proves itself to be an emotional masterpiece.

I wanted to like this SO. BAD. I think the story has potential, but I hate how it was executed. Was not impressed with Armie's acting at all, felt like maybe could've been better if someone else was Oliver. Timothee is talented, and I enjoyed the scenes with his parents. Other than that, total waste of $14.99 on iTunes.

I struggle to find the right words in order to praise this movie. I can't remember the last time I was this moved by a film; the stunning cinematography, the phenomenal actors and their performances and incredible direction all work together to form a masterpeice, and what I would consider to be the most beautiful love story I've ever seen. Your sexual orientation doesn't matter one bit when you watch this, as I didn't feel I had to label it in the particularly narrow catrgories of "gay" or "straight." To me this movie can only be defined as "love," and that's all I see it as. This film is a display of the purest, truest and rawest form of love that exists and its magnificent to watch. I find myself still unable to stop thinking about it, I know this is a film that will stick with me for the rest of my life!

reviews.review_title: Either you'll hate it or you'll love it.
reviews.content: This movie can connect anyone who has ever felt love at the deepest level, you may hate it or love it based upon your innermost feelings...

Such a beautiful film - about the innocence of young love and subsequent heartbreak.
The film gave me the chance to completely sink into Elio's world and I took this chance gratefully.
Everyone who experienced what Elio experienced was taken back to those memories and the one's who weren't that lucky were given the oppurtunity to get a grasp of what it must be like.
At the end the film(Elio's father) teaches a beautiful message with these themes:
One should not suffocate the emotions of heartbreak, one shouldn't waste these emotions, one should embrace these emotions before they become numb to them and as long as they're able to feel anything.
A fantastic performance from Armie Hammer, Michael Stuhlbarg and an outstanding one from Timothée Chalamet.
I also cried my heart out, thanks to Sufjan Stevens's fantastic score.

reviews.review_title: Don't hesitate just watch it and give it a chance
reviews.content:
I don't ever write reviews I just read them before sussing out whether it'd want to watch or not. However this movie affected me and I wanted to do so.I was hesitant to watch this as I didn't think this would be my kind of movie. I am so glad I did because I fell in love with it, so much so that I read the book is less than 24 hours and I don't even read often. This is such a beautiful movie with amazing scenes taking place in Italy. Both Elio & Oliver are amazing actors and for two straight men you honestly believe the chemistry between the two and just long for them to be together.
If you've ever been in love, or had a lust as strong as they do than you'll understand and it'll hit you hard and possibly make you cry. This is the sort of movie that makes you realise that youth is short, to just enjoy it and be yourself and if there is someone you care about, to actually do something about it.
I'm just hanging for a second one.

Brilliant script, beautiful cinematography, cohesive story about a very deep and rare first love experience. Literary analogy of the old beautiful sculptures coming out from the sea, like Ellio, coming out to his first love did not go unappreciated. Please do not think of this as a "gay movie " it goes way beyond that. Yes it deals with the difficulties of coming out ; but it is delicately woven into a rich deep fabric most of us have been lucky enough to experience in our lifetimes whether gay, straight, or bi. J'ai ador'e.

At present I have rated 827 feature films on IMDb, but not once have I left a review. I'm not a writer. However, Call Me by Your Name left me with a feeling so powerful that I simply had to put into words. Here goes...James Ivory's Oscar winning screenplay follows seventeen-year-old Elio and his father's twenty-something-year-old assistant, Oliver as they fall in love over the summer of 1983 in Northern Italy. It's a coming-of-age love story centered around Elio and Oliver's deep connection and the consequences of embracing their desires. Luca Guadagnino directs with Timothée Chalamet and Armie Hammer as the two leading men in this masterpiece of modern cinema.The film is beautifully shot and expertly directed whilst also featuring some truly incredible performances. Armie Hammer and Timothée Chalamet were both simply outstanding. Their awkward chemistry perfectly compliments the slow developing relationship between Elio and Oliver in the film. Initially, I struggled to see them together, but by the end I couldn't imagine them apart.Call Me by Your Name's most powerful moment comes during the film's conclusion in the form of a three and a half minute shot of Elio by the fire. As Sufjan Stevens' 'Visions of Gideon' plays, Elio experiences a myriad of emotions in what is one of the most moving scenes I've ever had the pleasure of viewing. Everyone remembers the first time they had their heart broken. You stop and feel every emotion with Elio as the world around him carries on. Timothée Chalamet, I have no words.As the credits rolled I couldn't help but wonder how long it will be until something beautiful arrives on our screens again.

reviews.review_title: Artistically beautiful but a bit icky
reviews.content: Visually and musically this is one of the best films i've ever seen. Despite this it was difficult to get over some aspects in which it was lacking. This was almost the perfect movie. I feel like if they got rid of the age gap and the cum peach i would have liked it a lot more.

A story about young love; that's how a friend described it to me. I guess that, to a certain extent, it is. Young love. Messy love. Infatuation. Your first love. Conflicting feelings. Feeling certain things for the first time.
A tightly contained love story, with a steep spiral of feelings up and a sudden crash down. Before you know it you're caught up in an emotional rollercoaster resulting in the most intense experience of your life. And before you know it you're left with an empty void in the shape of an Oliver (also goes by the name of Elio).The first thing I noticed about the film was the aesthetic and the feel. I liked the cinematography. The softness of the image. The setting in rural Italy, where teenagers seem to live somewhat secluded lives. Their world feels very small, adding a very cozy element to the world. The little village seems isolated from the troubles in the rest of the world and the likes of social media. A life of wine, cigarettes and loose blouses in hot summer weather.As the movie progresses and the story unfolds, I begin to realise there's probably not much of a plot. Everything about this film feels very slice of life. It allows you to take your time watching the scenes, the characters, and to take in the music and sounds very well.
Eventually the love story unfolds. I don't have much to say about it. It's a slice of life. The story arc is not the main focus. You just watch. So I watch the characters.
I don't know what the writer intended for you to think of Elio and Oliver, or what most people think of them. I don't like them.Elio. It feels to me like he has no regard for Marzia's feelings. Maybe even like he's using her. He's very caught up in his own feelings. He's young, stupid, conflicted and very much in love (the latter which I only truly grasped towards the end of the film).
It's understandable. But still. I can't not think of it while watching the main story unfold. It withholds me from getting immersed in Elio's character and the love story. He is either extremely naive when it comes to what his behaviour might do to Marzia, or is aware of what he's inevitably doing to her, but refuses to acknowledge and process those thoughts.
He's in love. She's in love. You'd guess he'd have the theory of mind ability to place himself in her shoes, especially since he now knows how intense and important love can be. I guess love makes you blind in more ways than one. Stupid Elio.Marzia is most definitely best girl. She tells Elio that she loves him. It came as kind of a shock to me, but now that I think about it it kind of fits. I feel like she's not in love with Elio in an infatuation kind of way. She actually loves him. Why, I don't know. She probably has her reasons. Anyway, she tells him she's not mad at him. She communicated her feelings and fears. Elio disregards those feelings and turns her fear into reality. He very explicitly hurts her... and she still loves him and truly wants to be his friend. She's too pure for this world.Note: Not to say that you can necessarily choose the way you love someone or don't. If you fall for someone and become infatuated and obsessed with that person, it's not like it's a choice. I mean with this that Elio isn't necessarily a worse person than Marzia. Although his actions regarding Marzia are hard to look past and ignore. I'm saying Marzia is the more likeable person. (because I judge people based on their actions?)I felt neutral towards Oliver in the beginning. He's not my type of guy, but I also didn't dislike him. He kept to himself. I warmed up to him when Elio and him got together and he showed his sensitive and understanding side. I'm not sure how I feel about the phone call at the end. I feel like Elio was being very sexual by saying whispering, almost moaning, his name over and over again. Oliver's breathing increased. That's not something your fiancee is gonna like.I'm not sure what to make of the monologue by Elio's dad at the end. I feel like he captures the essence of the movie. Feeling your feelings. Don't put them away, don't wish you never had them. I'm not sure what he meant by: most people go bankrupt by 30.Your heart is worn out and people don't look at your body anymore.He himself has never experienced that. He came close. Does he mean love? Or a love story? An infatuation love story. Like I wanted with her. Maybe.Had to fill in a lot from own experience.
Typical white romance- taking the unlimited privilege the protagonists have for granted and focuses on "clean" aesthetics and melancholic/deep script lines... i did enjoy it though

Call me by your name is a movie that talks about the summer love of elio and Oliver, a forbidden and intense love that gave me days of reflection and desire to love again. The movie starts showing Oliver arriving at elio's house where he would stay for the summer,even though it is not a scene of much interaction between the two I felt a certain connection a vibe between the two,and marzia, ah marzia the second option both in the movie and in the book who loved elio intensely but it was not totally reciprocal,when the two began to have an affair I exploded with rage, it seemed that she was only in the movie to mess up the couple and further mess up the mind of elio,I felt that he liked her, yes he did! But it wasn't that "I want to live my life by your side" love, it was "I like you but I don't see myself with you", she was blinded by love but I always thought that she felt that he liked Oliver. When they got together for the first time it was a dream come true, a goal fulfilled for the spectators, that kiss was beautiful, one of the best scenes in the movie I would say, the will and the insistence of Elio and the reluctance and the will of Oliver were two things that completed each other, their kiss didn't even seem fake, it was something staged, it was something pure and intense with a great acting of the actors, there was the beginning of their affair, the beginning of the deepest possible summer love. The peach scene, the dreaded peach scene that at the same time shocks us and also gives us a "WOW", I believe that there is some message through this scene, it can be interpreted in many ways, I like to think that Oliver wanted to prove his love and that's why he ate that peach, or he's just a pervert, and I believe that it was a moment of reflection for Elio, you know, that was a kind of way for him to discover himself, to express himself, and a disgusting and sensational scene. The trip, oh my, the trip Romantics that made me smile and worry,there I thought it wouldn't be just any summer love there I thought they would drop everything and live together forever,but then there was the goodbye,the dreaded and painful goodbye,I felt an emptiness in that scene,an immense sadness,elio comes back home Without Oliver and there you realize that there is no longer the summer love of the two but still have hope,until the connection scene.... The news that Oliver gives the crying face of elio and the feeling that Oliver just used elio to satisfy himself from the anger sadness hate all feeling,elio starting to cry and the last scene of the movie of him crying and the credits going up and something spectacular and something beautiful and sad to see,surely call me by your name and one of the best movies so much that won nothing less than an Oscar.

Call me by your name wasn't as enjoyable as I hoped. The cinematography was interesting and kept me entertained. The colours and the aesthetic were very pleasing and uplifting. The sets were absolutely enchanting. The characters were kind of boring, and didn't really have any specific traits that I could tell you about. There was lots of unnecessary scenes which dragged on and made me uninterested. 
The relationship between Elio and Oliver, while heartwarming, the age gap set me a little on edge, especially because Elio is only 17.

reviews.review_title: Without judgments, without scandals and without controversy.
reviews.content:
The director Luca Guadagnino brings us a romantic drama that is made in the most complete and convincing way possible. Get to show that we should all have the opportunity to live the first mad passion of a summer love.And that is why there could not be a better place for this story than in a town in northern Italy in the summer of 1983. (Curiously, at the stage where the first AIDS infections and their different forms of transmission began to be known. ) Elio, an intelligent young man of 17 years, played by a great Timothée Chalamet, who knows how to play the piano with great mastery among a lot of other things, is in full discovery of his sexuality when he meets Oliver, played by Armie Hammer, that embodies the most authentic attitude of confidence and American boldness.
Suddenly those sunny days and to a certain extent, boring of a common summer change for the attention that Elio awakens the perfect American. Soon a love story is created without judgments, without scandals or polemics, in the sexual encounter of two people who fall in love. So natural, as if it were a story of the present, the characters do not enter into conflicts for their tastes and desires and embark on a relationship that in 83 was not as assimilable as it can be today.
The director gets a true intimacy between the protagonists. Almost all physical contact is an electrifying process that transforms the protagonist from a shy child to a bold young man, to achieve the self-confidence he found in Oliver.The bright sun reflected in the pond, the sunsets that fall through the rooms of the great house, the intellectual atmosphere that the parents of Elio give off, with the freshness of the fruit of the season, passing through the apricots, and the beauty that surrounds all the natural space where the story unfolds are the elements that have a great natural parallelism with the protagonists.
Since the previous films by Guadarnino ("Yo soy el amor" 2009 and "Blinded by the Sun" 2015) he has shown that he knows how to appreciate the beauty of the actors and turns them into something more than aesthetic objects. Becoming an explorer of the psyche of his characters and that weaves the scenes of love thus perpetuating in the memory of the public.

reviews.review_title: A gem for an older person's looking back over life
reviews.content:
Timothée Chalamet portrays youthful sexual passion powerfully in the Call Me by Your Name. For a heterosexual male to assume that role so seamlessly is, for me, akin to Gwyneth Paltrow's Oscar winning role in Shakespeare in Love. Crossing gender or crossing sexuality is not easy and requires great depth of acting ability. Chalamet's portrayal required a sexual courage most of us presumably don't have.
A young person viewing the film might not recognize the force of the father's last speech since it values the boy's love relationship and subsequent pain from an older person's point of view. That those moments of pain could be a precious part of a first passionate love is perhaps more apparent to those of us who have aged considerably. The setting and pace of a summer's leisure may also appeal most to those in the same economic bracket as the classically educated family described. How many of us can while away summer months in such a lofty cultural manner?
The film's emotional reverberations are deep in the universal valuing of passionate young love, where neither boy nor man reveals to the other what this love might mean. In 1983, Oliver's choice to marry a woman is probably a necessary one from his point of view. Elio, at age seventeen, has no adult thought of a future as a gay male in an inhospitable social climate. He simply desires. Hence his pain is inconsolable as he grieves into the flames of a dining room fire place. Yet his face eventually shows resolve, strength. He will learn in time, we are told.

I was a little concerned about some rather unsettling pedo-vibes that may have unintentionally resulted from this. I think this may have been exacerbated by Elio's obvious infatuation with Oliver and a much less defined attraction on Oliver's part.And I was a little dismayed that the girls in this film were treated and used with such disdained -- basically experiments and/or beards as the two gay characters came to terms with their own sexuality. It impacted how much I liked the main characters -- particularly towards the end of the movie when Oliver had that smug scene on the bus leaving town. I cannot help but feel for all these heartbroken women who get run over by the sad/terrible forces in this movie and who are victims in their own right. All are collateral damage (including Oliver's future wife) and that makes me even more sad for the characters in this movie. reviews.review_title: Thoughtful drama that will ultimately take your breath away.
reviews.content: Directed by Luca Guadagnino from a script James Ivory, 'Call Me By Your Name' marks the final instalment in his Desire trilogy started with 'I Am Love' and 'A Bigger Splash'. In keeping with his previous films, this latest chapter is imbued with the same kind of visual aesthetic and cerebral exchanges. Everyone here is smart, everyone has important work to do and the drama is framed inside the ambitions (or the lack of) of its characters....laced with subtle subtexts that ultimately puncture each character's meaning.Time moves slowly. Hard baked in the Italian sunshine, the film's pace mirrors the balmy environment of its story. That said, in the experienced hands of 'A Passage To India's James Ivory the dialogue is both believable and laced with subtle subtexts that ultimately puncture each character's meaning.In the role of Elio, actor Timothée Chalamet embodies the precociousness of youth caught on the cusp of adulthood. By turn louche and languid, his stick-thin frame peppered with penetrating eyes dart out at his house guest. As Oliver, Armie Hammer also impresses. Playing against type and building upon his recent run of credible performances (as evidenced in 'Final Portrait') Hammer again convinces in all regards. A notably graceful dance between both men, neither actor leads the other and the gears of their relationship change so imperceptibly that, by its close, 'Call Me By Your Name' immediately warrants a second viewing.In fact Guadagnino's movie is a film that saves its very best for last. In a beautifully judged piece of both acting and scriptwriting, the final twenty minutes serve up a scene so deeply affecting that it nearly eclipses the finale. -You'll know when you see it. Coupled with an extended end section that bleeds right through the credits, this is also film that will leave you in no doubt as to Timothée Chalamet's talent or his much deserved Best Actor nomination. Cherish these closing embers as they hold the key to a smouldering, thoughtful drama that will ultimately take your breath away.

Not to single out this particular premise, but films revolving around gay couples have been terrific over the last decade or so. There was a spark when 2005's Brokeback Mountain was released, which eventually brought us to foreign films like Blue Is the Warmest Colour being nominated for a Golden Globe or Moonlight winning best picture at the Oscars. Call Me by Your Name is the latest film to probably receive many nominations in the coming months, and believe me, the praise is not false. Being a fan of 2015's A Bigger Splash, I was looking forward to Luca Guadagnino's follow-up feature film, and I believe this to be an improvement in the best ways. Exploring the hardships of life and what it means to just kick back and relax every now and then, Call Me by Your Name is a film that's been sticking with me since my viewing of it. While it admittedly won't be able to draw in everyone to the theatres, here is why I believe this to be a fantastic, award-worthy picture.

Written by James Ivory and directed by Luca Guadagnino, Call Me by Your Name follows a family that lets Oliver, an older graduate student, live in their home for the summer. While this is a common thing, what's not too common is that Elio, their son, will eventually grow romantic feelings toward this man, convincing him to become his lover for the summer. From the age gap between them and having to hide it from the family, their situation isn't an easy one, nor will it be for some audience members, but it really is a wonderful story. This is easily a story that could've stirred up controversy if it hadn't been done with taste, and because of how it was made, I just couldn't take my eyes off the screen. This was made entirely possible by the incredibly devoted performances by Timothée Chalamet and Armie Hammer.

Hammer has had his ups and downs through the years, appearing in Oscar-winning films as well as some of the worst films of the year, so his performance here was the most shocking to me. Yes, he's been talent in nearly everything he's been in, but he really gave his all in this performance and I honestly don't think he'll ever be better than he was in Call Me by Your Name. On the other hand, young Chalamet has a very bright future ahead of him. Being a relatively new actor, his chemistry with Hammer was impeccably astounding. Their relationship took a while to grow on me, but once it completely won me over, I found myself wondering if there was anything to really complain about.

If I had to complain about anything, it would be in its extreme pressure to try your patience. There are very long sequences of silence, making you relax and take in either a romantic moment or the scenery around them, which I also found poetic at the same time, so I actually have trouble coming up with issues, but I have to admit that I did find the movie slow at times. Yes, it's meant to be slow, which is why that complaint isn't exactly valid, but I just have to be honest.

In the end, this is a truly remarkable piece of dramatic filmmaking and there are some very memorable scenes that keep replaying themselves in my head. One scene in particular that involves Elio and his father Mr. Perlman (played magnificently by Michael Stuhlbarg) toward the end had me in tears. From the brilliantly written screenplay, to the poetic cinematography, to the terrifically calm direction, Call Me by Your Name isn't a movie that I would send the average moviegoer out to see, but if you're a hardcore film fan, I think you'll end up loving this movie.
